dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet, working-class residential street in Ireland, ear 1950s. It’s morning, but it’s still dark. One of the fron doors opens, and out slips EILIS - early twenties, open-f pretty without knowing it. She closes the door quietly be her and walks quickly up the street. There is a hissed call from behind her. She turns, and he sister ROSE - thirty, attractive, slender, pale - is runn after her, in nightdress and bare feet, holding out a pie of bread and jam. Eilis takes it from her, makes a face t show how grateful she is.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (mouthing) Go back to bed. Rose nods, tiptoes back to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s the early mass, and the church has only a smattering worshippers. Eilis is kneeling and praying with two other women: MISS KELLY, fifties, thick glasses, a constant loo disapproval on her face, and MARY, the same age as Eilis, large and simple-minded - her mouth is usually open, indicating her lack of comprehension at more or less any given moment. Eilis yawns. Miss Kelly shoots her a look. Chastened, Eilis stifles the yawn and looks fixedly ahead

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, there is weak daylight. Mary and Eilis wait whil Miss Kelly finds her keys and opens the side-door to her shop. This is clearly not a normal morning for Eilis - sh has something on her mind. She watches Miss Kelly careful trying to judge the right moment to speak to her. The doo opens, Mary walks into the shop, leaving Miss Kelly and E bringing up the rear.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Miss Kelly, might I talk to you later?

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: Not if what you’re going to say will cause trouble for me in some way or another. End of conversation. Eilis closes her eyes for a moment, fearful of the confrontation to come.  'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kelly turns on the light, and we see the shop for th first time. It’s a well-stocked, and well-kept, grocery store, but it almost certainly hasn’t changed since the 1920s. Eilis walks to the back of the shop to collect the bread, which has obviously been there since the previous and places it on the counter. While Miss Kelly takes a pi of long, yellow paper out of its packet, Mary places a la carefully under the old piece, which is stuck to the ceil and covered with the bodies of dead flies. Later. A male customer is buying a single cigarette from Eilis. Miss Kelly is peering through the shop window from angle.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: The nine o’clock mass is over, girls. Here they come. Later. The shop is packed - customers standing three or f deep at the counter. Eilis and Mary are coping as best th can; Miss Kelly is directing them, in a way designed to c maximum resentment. Miss Kelly spies a well-dressed woman standing well back, and smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: Mrs Brady, what would you like this morning?

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRADY
dialogues.text: Half-a-dozen rashers, please.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: Of course. Eilis will get that for you now. Eilis is about to serve a shabbier woman standing right i front of the counter. Eilis looks at her helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: SHABBY WOMAN
dialogues.text: (aggrieved) I was next.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: And you still are. Mary, if you serve Mr O'Leary back there, will you make a mess of it? I suppose you will. Let’s see. Mary is stung by the barb. Miss Kelly doesn’t notice and doesn’t care anyway.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Mr O'Leary? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 3.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mr O'Leary, like Mrs Brady, is well towards the back of t scrum. Miss Kelly’s favouritism seems designed to cause resentment and frustration, but the customers seem used t her arbitrary treatment of them, and there are no outward signs of dissent. Miss Kelly turns her attention to a tim looking woman standing right in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: TIMID WOMAN
dialogues.text: (quietly) I need some shoe polish.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: Shoe polish? Ah, but that’s not really a Sunday item, now, is it? These people need things for their dinner or their tea. Why couldn't you have remembered yesterday? Miss Kelly leans over the counter to stare at the timid woman’s shoes. The timid woman stares at the counter, humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: Because it looks like you needed it yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: TIMID WOMAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Miss Kelly sighs deeply, shakes her head, and goes to fin the offending item.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kelly locks the door of the shop behind the last customer. Eilis stops tidying up and waits until the door locked before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Miss Kelly...

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: (tetchy) I hadn't forgotten. Spit it out, whatever it is.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I'm..I’m away to America. Miss Kelly likes to think she knows everything, but this gives her pause. She soon recovers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 4.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: (scornful) Whose idea was that?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Father Flood in New York arranged it. Rose used to play golf with him, when he lived here. He sponsored me. He... he found me a job, and got me a visa, and..

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: Well, we won't be needing you back here.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I don’t sail for a month. I could work every Sunday until I go.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: I shall want to train a new girl up straight away.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: But I could help.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: No, thank you. She starts to turn her back on Eilis, but she has one las thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: Your poor sister.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (surprised) My sister?

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: Oh, mothers are always being left behind in this country. But Rose...That’s the end for her, isn’t it? She’ll be looking after your mother for the rest of her life. This time she does turn her back and walk away. EXT. NANCY’S HOUSE. NIGHT 6 Eilis is knocking at the door of a house not dissimilar t her own. She scarcely has time to complete a second knock and the door flies open. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 5.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her friend NANCY, already wearing her coat, smiles at Eil pulls the door shut behind her, and starts walking off do the street with Eilis trailing in her wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy and Eilis walking arm-in-arm down the street. Now w can get a chance to look at Nancy properly: she’s staggeringly pretty, film-star pretty. It helps that she’ dressed up and made up to go out - Eilis looks a little w by comparison, even though she’s made an effort too - but even so, she’s a stunner.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: You look beautiful, Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: You look so beautiful it makes me despair of this place. Nancy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: You're the prettiest girl in County Wexford. You should be able to choose any man you want. And we're hoping that George Sheridan from the rugby club looks your way. The scornful way she emphasises the social institution suggests that she doesn’t think he’s much of a catch.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (sufficiently excited to miss the point) Do you think he might?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Of course he will. I know you like him, Nancy, but he’s not Gary Cooper, is he? And those boys, with their hair-oil and their blazers.. She shudders her distaste.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: He has beautiful eyes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 5A.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: And he’s going to come into a beautiful shop in the Market Square.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (changing the subject) Why didn’t you wear your blue dress? Now it is Eilis’s turn to look a little discomfited.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Are you asking why I didn’t make more of an effort? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 6.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They have reached the small hall where the dance they are attending is taking place. They join a small queue to get all girls.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What if one of the boys from the rugby club asked you to dance? Wouldn't you like the pleasure of telling him it’s too late? They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy and Eilis are leaning against the wall sipping lemonades. There aren’t many men this early in the evenin and the dance-floor is almost deserted. Suddenly there is buzz from the girls scattered around the place. Eilis’s e are drawn to the same place as everyone else’s: to the do A group of young men, dressed almost identically, and jus Eilis described - blazers and hair-oil - are coming in. O of them is JIM, who we will meet much later. These young men exude a confidence bordering on arrogance they’re hard to like en masse - and consequently the unif looks slightly sinister. They ignore everyone in the room make their way to the soft drinks bar. Eilis rolls her ey Nancy is blushing. Later. Nancy and Eilis are still waiting. Eilis is watchi the rugby club boys, Nancy is looking anywhere but. The camera picks out George, who is tall, confident, as oily his friends - and no Gary Cooper.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: He’s looked over here twice already.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: He hasn’t!

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: He’s walking over here now.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (still looking the other way ) He’s not! He is. We see him. Nancy, however, still has her back to

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (impatient) Why would I keep lying to you about what George Sheridan’s doing? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 7.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: George arrives. He nods at Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Would you like to dance? Nancy is almost too nervous to nod her head. Moments later. George and Nancy on the dance floor. Over their shoulders the camera picks up Eilis, making her way towards the door, holding her coat. A couple of the rugby clubbers whisper and snigger as they watch her leave. INT. DINING ROOM, EILIS’S HOUSE. EVENING 9 It’s Eilis’s last night at home. Eilis, her mother MARY a her sister Rose, are eating, initially in silence. The so of cutlery hitting crockery only serves to emphasise the tension and the sadness of the evening. Eilis keeps sneak glances at the rest of her family, trying to gauge how unhappy they are. There’s no outward trace. Rose and her mother are both concentrating on their food, determined to give nothing a Eventually Eilis has to say what is on her mind.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (quietly) I wish I had written to Father Flood about you, Rose.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Me? I have a job. You had a couple of hours on a Sunday working for Nettles Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (mildly disapproving) You shouldn’t call her that.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I think it’s quite a kind name. Considering she’s actually a terrible old witch. Mary makes a scandalised face.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I don’t want to spend my last evening talking about her.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Good. But nobody knows what they do want to talk about. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 8.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They say it’s hotter there in the summer, and colder in the winter. Mary puts her knife and fork down despairingly.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (with deep but clearly displaced anxiety) What in Heaven’s name will she do about clothes?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She’1l buy them, mother.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She doesn’t want to be wasting her money on clothes.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She won't have much choice. She’1l be there... She stops herself from finishing the sentence. An even de and unhappier silence falls on the table. INT. EILIS’S BEDROOM. NIGHT 10 Close on an old and very large suitcase. It’s about two- thirds full of Eilis’s things. Pull back to show Rose and Eilis peering into it.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (wry) There. It wasn’t so hard to decide after all.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Is that really everything you own? Oh, Eilis. I should have looked after you better. I should have taken you shopping twice a year, summer and winter.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: You’ve bought most of the clothes in this case. That’s one of the reasons I’m going, because I can’t buy my own.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: If it was just that, I'd spend every penny I had on you, gladly. But I can’t buy you a future. I can’t buy you the kind of life you need. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 11 12 13 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 9.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (whispers ) I know. (Beat) But you’1ll come to see me there one day?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: And you'll look after yourself?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to worry about me.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: And I’1l come home to visit, won’t I? Because I couldn't bear it if... Rose has to stop this, because she can’t bear it either.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You haven’t packed your shoes yet. They'll take up a bit of room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis is wedged at the deck-rail of a large passenger lin along with a lot of other emigres, her large suitcase in front of her. Among the crowd on the dock below her are R and Mary. There are a lot of tears, from passengers and t people they are leaving behind. Rose and Mary, however, l Eilis, are keeping everything in. The ship blasts its hor announce its imminent departure; everyone jumps and laugh nervously, and the waving becomes more frantic. Rose and Mary, however, suddenly turn away from the boat and push through the crowd. Rose looks back helplessly and blows E a kiss. Eilis watches the backs of the two of them until disappear out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis bumps her case down the narrow steps deep in the bo of the boat. She reaches a corridor and examines the sign the wall directing passengers to their berths. She has to descend still deeper into the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis’s cabin is tiny and windowless, and she has to shar with someone: there are two bunk beds. She wedges her suitcase into an available space. She opens the bathroom door. The bathroom is tiny. It contains a toilet and a sink. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 10.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There is another door, apparently leading into the next cabin. A sign on the door says ‘UNLOCK WHEN NOT IN USE’. Eilis pushes it open and sees two middle-aged women unpacking.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Sorry. She shuts it again quickly. She doesn’t know what to do, lies down on the bottom bunk with her hands behind her he staring. She closes her eyes, but suddenly the cabin door bursts open and a glamorous blonde, late thirties, bustle to the room with a large trunk. This is GEORGINA, her cab mate.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: off! Eilis sits up and stares at her, uncomprehending. Georgin waves a ticket at her. GEORGINA (CONT’D) Number one. Bottom bunk. That’s mine. You’re on the top. Eilis scrambles up the ladder to her bed. She can’t sit u the ceiling is too low - so she has to lie down, and is therefore unable to make eye-contact with Georgina throug the scene.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: This is hell. Never again.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (trying to be friendly) Never again to America?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: The mistake was coming home from America in the first place. I'd do anything to get out of this horrible cabin, and I mean anything. Let’s go for a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I don’t. Georgina rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Suit yourself. I’1l see you later. Unless I find a nice man in First to smoke with. She bustles out.  14 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 10A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis is on her own in the Third Class dining room. She i eating a plate of very brown and very unappetising-lookin mutton stew. She eats as much as she can, although a lot the meat is gristle, which she has to extract from her mo with a napkin, as discreetly as possible. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 15 16 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 11.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She finishes, dabs her mouth with the napkin. The under- employed waiter comes over immediately to clear away her plate.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: It’s good to see that not everybody's put off their dinner by the weather forecast. Eilis looks at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (cheerful) It’s supposed to be a rough one tonight, so none of the other passengers are eating. A few spoonfuls of soup, maybe, but not the mutton stew. Comprehension dawns. Eilis looks stricken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis is standing in her nightgown, clutching her toothbr and toothpaste. She is waiting outside the locked bathroo She taps on the door. Nothing. She waits a few moments. S puts her ear to the door, but the only noise comes from t ships engines - in Third Class, a loud, deep constant. Sh grimaces suddenly, and closes her eyes. She’s sweating. S knocks on the bathroom door again.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (to the door) Oh, please unlock it. She can’t wait any longer. She stumbles out into the corr looking for a toilet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .--Nothing. She tries to go upstairs to the Second Class cabins, but the door at the bottom of the stairs is locke She's desperate now. In an alcove of the corridor, she se mop and bucket. She picks up the bucket, ready to throw u it - but as soon as she does so, she realises that her problems are at the other end. She puts the bucket on the floor, squats over it. She looks around desperately for something to wipe herself with, but there is only the mop She hates herself, and everything that has led to her bei here. She starts to throw up.  17 18 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis comes back in, holding the mop and the bucket. She knocks on the bathroom door again. No answer, but this ti she hears the sound of retching. She pukes into the bucke For a moment there is a little contrapuntal symphony of retching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis is asleep on the bottom bunk. Close on her face - g tinged, sweaty. A hand touches her face, and Eilis opens eyes. It’s Georgina.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry about the smell. And the bucket.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: (gently) Oh, don’t worry. The whole boat stinks. Even First Class. I’ve just been thrown out of there, by the way, so you’ll have me throwing up in here too.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: The bathroom door was locked all night.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: (angry on Eilis’s behalf) Oh, those bastards. That’s what people do. They keep the bathroom for themselves on rough nights. We'll fix them. She fishes in a handbag and finds a nail-file. Deftly, sh unlocks the bathroom door. There’s nobody in there. Quick she pulls her trunk into the bathroom and jams it against door on the other side. There is now no room in front of toilet.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: It won’t be very comfortable. But at least it’s ours now. They smile at each other. Almost immediately there is a furious knocking on the bathroom door. Georgina hurls her against the door with a fury.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Fuck off! Do you hear me? Fuck off! If you’d been nice last night, we would have played fair. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 13.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But now you’ve got no toilet for five days, you bastards. Eilis laughs, and then winces.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Go on, you can use it. I’m going to get us some water. That’s all you're allowed. You’1l bring it all up again, but you won’t feel so bad. And you'll be right as rain after a night’s sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgina comes into the cabin. Eilis emerges from the sho drying herself. She’s looking better.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: (mock-dramatic) We have a peace treaty.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: With next door?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Yes. They have given their solemn word never to lock the bathroom door when they’re not using it. They know they’re out of their depth with me. The women smile at each other. GEORGINA (CONT’D) Are you going to America to live?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: You have papers and everything?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes. And a job.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: You have family there?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No. A beat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 14.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Well. You’1l make friends easy enough. Where will you be staying?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: In Brooklyn. New York. Georgina smiles wrily.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Ah. Well, try and remember that sometimes it’s nice to meet people who don’t know your auntie. Just every now and again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis and Georgina are leaning on the rails of the third- class deck, looking out to sea.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I haven't been sick for hours.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: It’s nice, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m very hungry.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: That's why you haven’t been sick for hours. We can eat soon. Maybe tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgina and Eilis eating in the canteen. The journey is nearly over, so there are more diners now. Both women loo tired and pale. Georgina studies Eilis.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Oh, dear. We’1ll have to do something with you. They’1ll put you in quarantine or something if you try to enter the country looking like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgina is pulling clothes out of Eilis’s case.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Nothing fancy. You mustn’t look like a tart. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 23 24 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 15.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She carries on pulling the plain-looking clothes out of t case. GEORGINA (CONT’D) Oh. Well. Looking like a tart isn’t going to be a problem. She finds a white dress with a red floral pattern. GEORGINA (CONT’D) That’s not too bad.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: My sister gave me that.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Wear it with this... She finds a plain cardigan. GEORGINA (CONT’D) And this. She pulls out a plain scarf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis is in the queue to get in to the immigration centre looking anxiously ahead of her. Her compatriots, men and women and children, are all around her. She is wearing ma up, and she looks very different - much less naive. Over her shoulder, we see A VISTA OF THE MANHATTAN SKYLIN Eilis stares at it for a little while, wide-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Don’t look too innocent. I’11 put some rouge and mascara on you. And perhaps some eye-liner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis inside, approaching the officials. We watch with he a family is in the process of being turned away: a man, h wife, a toddler and a baby. The woman (and baby) are cryi the man distraught. They are clearly poor: the man’s boot have holes in them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Polish your shoes, and don’t cough, whatever you do. And stand up straight. Eilis remembers to stand tall. She’s looking at all the people around her, and the hard-luck stories they represe (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 25 26 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 16.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A few minutes later. Eilis is showing her papers to the official.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Don’t be rude, or pushy, but don’t look nervous. It’s as if Eilis remembers the advice even as we’re heari it: she suddenly lifts her eyes from the official’s shoul towards a point ahead of him - towards America.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Think like an American. You have to know where you’re going. The official hands Eilis her papers back and ushers her through. She walks towards the light on the other side, a suddenly the sun blanches out everything; we just see a silhouette, walking into nowhere. EXT. MRS. KEHOE’S STREET. EARLY EVENING 25 Eilis is struggling with her suitcase down a dimly-lit Brooklyn residential street. INT. DINING ROOM, MRS. KEHOE’S HOUSE. EVENING 26 Round a dining table in a basement kitchen are five girls including Eilis, and a middle-aged lady. This is the impeccably-dressed landlady of Eilis’s lodging-house in Brooklyn, MRS KEHOE. The girls are standing and holding hands, while Mrs Kehoe says grace, so we get a good look them. Two of the girls - PATTY and DIANA - are young and attractive. Patty is the only native American in the hous the rest are Irish. Patty and Diana are a double-act, fir friends and quick to defend each other. SHEILA is older, glamorous in a femme fatale way, with a chequered history There is constant tension between Patty and Diana on one and Sheila on the other. MISS MCADAM is prim, plain, bespectacled, severe-looking and from Belfast.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: Bless us, oh Lord, and these thy gifts which we are about to receive from thy bounty through Christ our Lord, Amen.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MCADAM
dialogues.text: Amen. Patty and Diana exchange glances and try not to laugh at McAdam's piety. Everyone sits down to eat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 17.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: I saw you had a letter today, Diana. Any news?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Mr de Valera has had another operation on his eyes, she says. He’s been in Holland.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: (dismissively) I don’t want news I can read in a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: (artfully) Anyway, we would describe Mr de Valera as “politics”, would we not, Mrs Kehoe? And we do not like politics at the dinner table. Her firmness is parodic - she’s making fun of Mrs Kehoe, seems not to notice.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: We don’t.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (aggrieved) It’s not politics, to talk about eye operations.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: It is if the eyes belong to a politician. And I don’t like to talk about hospitals very much, either. Patty, have you had any luck with that cold cream?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: No, Mrs Kehoe. It still hasn’t come in. I asked Miss Tyler in Cosmetics. And I showed her the advertisement.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to have to travel all the way to Manhattan for a jar of cold cream. Maybe you could have a look in Bartocci’s for me, Eilis?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes, Mrs Kehoe.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Oh, Bartocci’s is bound to have it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26 27 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 18.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 26 Patty rolls her eyes. Mrs Kehoe There are

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: She doesn’t know for sure, Mrs Kehoe. She’s saying that Bartocci’s is a better store than Webster's, just to get at Patty.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: They’re both very good, and you girls are lucky to be working there. Eilis, from the look of you, you have greasy skin, is that right? What do you do about that?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Just...Well, I wash it, Mrs Kehoe. With soap.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MCADAM
dialogues.text: There’s nothing wrong with soap. Soap was good enough for Our Lord. I expect.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: And which brand did he use, Miss McAdam? Does the Bible tell you that?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: And our Lord was a man, anyway. He didn’t care about greasy skin. shakes her head in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: (sternly) Ladies. No more talk about Our Lord's complexion at dinner, please. (Beat) Girls, you will help Eilis find something suitable, won’t you? enthusiastic murmurings of consent. Eilis tries to look pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis in the dark in her small bedroom, trying to sleep. hot, and the house is alive with noise, even late at nigh There are footsteps on the ceiling above her, and the sound of a lavatory chain flushing through the wall. Down the hallway, there is the sound of a whispered conversation between two of the girls. Eilis gives up on sleep, opens eyes properly and stares at the ceiling.  28 29 30 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 19. EXT. MRS KEHOE’S STREET. DAY 28 Early morning. Eilis shutting the door of Mrs Kehoe’s brownstone behind her. She walks up the quiet street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera picks Eilis out in the bustle of people. She’s waiting to cross the road; on the other side is Bartocci’ the department store where she works. INT. STAFF ROOM, BARTOCCI’S. DAY 30 Eilis takes her clock card from the holder in the wall, p it in the machine, waits for the heavy thud of the punch, puts the card back in the holder. She walks to her locker puts on the blue uniform that all the female shop assista wear. As she changes, a colleague, DOROTHY - the same age Eilis, but chattier, - and cattier - starts to change at locker next to hers.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Good morning. They change in silence for a couple of moments.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Did you go out last night? Eilis looks at her blankly. Dorothy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Out. The opposite of in.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I went to see a movie with my boyfriend. Eilis carries on changing. Dorothy becomes exasperated by Eilis’s lack of engagement, and embarks on both sides of conversation.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: “What did you see, Dorothy?” “I saw ‘The Quiet Man’, Eilis. They filmed it in Ireland.” “Oh, I’m from Ireland.” “I know you are. That’s why I thought you might be interested.” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 31 32 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 20.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (sincerely) Thank you. Eilis finishes changing and walks out of the room. Doroth watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 31
dialogues.text: INT. BARTOCCI’S. DAY 32 Close on a small metal case with a hinged door on one end see Eilis’s hand putting cash and a docket into the holde and closing the door. Eilis pushes the holder firmly into tube, and it whizzes up to the ceiling. The camera follows the tube system a little way and then pulls back, to reveal the women’s department of a beautif 1950s department store in all its quiet, dignified splend lots of dark wood, lots of lovingly-arranged items of clothing. Very few of us have ever seen, or can remember properly, a store like this, but we ache for its loss any Eilis is standing behind the counter, smiling pleasantly customer, a middle-aged white woman.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t be a moment. They wait in silence. A few yards away, and unnoticed by Eilis initially, stands Eilis’s supervisor MISS FORTINI - thirtysomething, utterly devoted to the store. She’s watc Eilis carefully. Finally Eilis spots her. Miss Fortini clearly makes her uncomfortable. Eilis tries to maker herself look busy. Sh puts the stocking that the woman has bought into a bag, a then starts to write something down on a docket. Unseen b the customer, Miss Fortini tells Eilis in mime to speak a to smile. Eilis freezes even more. Miss Fortini steps tow her.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (in a rush) Is it still hot out there? I haven’t been outside since this morning but I can tell that it might be. Very. It just..looks it. She ends this awkward little speech with a forced smile, it’s enough to ward off Miss Fortini, who switches her attention elsewhere for a moment, to Eilis’s visible reli

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: It’s warm, yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 33 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 21.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The metal tube returns with a whoosh and a clank. Eilis extracts the change and the docket, and hands both to the customer. The moment she has gone, Miss Fortini returns.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: Remember: if people like it here, they’11 come back. Eilis nods, as if Miss Fortini has said something deep, o interesting.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: So you treat every customer as if she’s a new friend. Is that a deal?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’ll try.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: (gently) It’s not a matter of trying. It’s what you have to do. (Beat) Do you try to wear panties every day? The analogy is slightly off, inappropriate, and Eilis is thrown for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No. I mean, I don’t try. I..I just put them on.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: You see what I’m saying?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch time. While Eilis eats her grilled cheese sandwich the counter, she watches her fellow diners - male colleag smoking and joking, girlfriends talking animatedly, peopl their own reading the newspaper. Everyone seems to know w they're doing there except Eilis - everyone seems comfort in their own skin, absorbed in their environment. Eilis l anxious and uncomfortable and lost. She finishes her sandwich, swallows as quickly as she can, catches the eye the young, handsome waiter.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Could I have the bill please? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 22.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: I hope that when I go through the pearly gates, the first sound I hear is you asking me for the bill in that lovely Irish brogue. Eilis smiles nervously. She leaves some money on the coun and stands up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow, sweetheart. Eilis gives a quick, thin smile and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis comes out of the lunch joint and exhales. 35 INT. DINING ROOM, MRS. KEHOE’S HOUSE. EVENING. 35 The girls and Mrs Kehoe are eating dinner, in exactly the same formation as the first time we saw them.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: Have they told you a date for the nylon sale yet, Eilis? We’ve never had a Bartocci’s girl living here. (She taps her nose) We may get some inside information.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I haven't been told anything.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: I‘1l bet you wouldn't let on if you had.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: She’s that sort. More loyal to her bosses than to her friends.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Like a Red spy. Eilis is flustered.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: (wearily) Oh, dear God.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: I‘1l thank you to keep His name out of a conversation about nylons, thank you very much. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 23.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He might be everywhere, but He’s not in Bartocci’s on sale day.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Mrs Kehoe. They all settle back down.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: I was glad to see you finally got some letters from home today, Eilis. Eilis looks up from her plate as if electrocuted.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Did I? I..I forgot to check. She half-stands - she can’t wait.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: They’1l still be there after dinner.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Oh. Yes. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door bursts open and Eilis comes rushing in, clutchin her letters. She sits down on the bed, and tears the firs one open. As soon as she starts reading she begins to wee uncontrollably. We hear ROSE’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.0O)
dialogues.text: The big news here is that since you left, Mummy has stopped shopping at Nettles Kelly's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose is at her desk, writing to Eilis.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As you know, her bread wasn’t always fresh, and she overcharged for everything. And she’s awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose’s voice fades out. Eilis’s crying reaches a new leve she has to stop reading because she can no longer see. Th banal domestic details of her old life intensify her homesickness to an agonising pitch.  37 38 39 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 24. INT. DINING ROOM, MRS. KEHOE’S HOUSE, DAY 37 The girls are eating their breakfast and ignoring Eilis, is still reading and re-reading her letters. She’s not crying, but she’s pale and unhappy-looking.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I haven’t told her to her face. There’s no need. She knows that she overcharges and her bread’s not fresh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis at what is obviously her usual position in the dine Her sandwich and glass of milk are untouched in front of She's reading the letters again.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We talk about you every evening, of course. We want to know everything. I’m sure you're busy, but even if your letters were two hundred pages, they wouldn’t be long enough for your mother. Take care of yourself. Love. INT. BARTOCCI’S. DAY 39 Eilis at her counter. Her customary look of timidity has replaced by something altogether more despairing, and as serves a customer, she is quite clearly struggling for composure. Miss Fortini watches from a distance. The cust takes her purchase and leaves. Miss Fortini walks up to h

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: Is it your time of the month? Eilis shakes her head. MISS FORTINI (CONT’D) So what is it? Eilis cannot stops the tears. She shakes her head again. MISS FORTINI (CONT’D) You cannot carry on like this. You must either cheer up, or pretend to cheer up. Take some time off now. Go and sit in the staff room.  40 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis sitting on her own in the large, shabby staff room, full of overflowing ashtrays and coffee-cups with lipstic rings on them. She’s still holding her glass of water. Dorothy, her colleague, comes in.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I forgot something. She rummages, in a desultory fashion, through a pile of newspapers and magazines on a table.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I heard you pulled a stunt. Nice work if you can get it, sitting on a chair in the staff room sipping a glass of water. The door opens, and Miss Fortini comes into the room with FATHER FLOOD. Father Flood is bearded, pleasant-looking, clearly trustworthy. He smiles warmly at Eilis.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, Eilis. This is all my fault. Eilis looks at him, surprised. Father Flood is about to continue, but he looks at Dorothy first. FATHER FLOOD (CONT’D) Would you give us a moment? Thank you. Dorothy leaves, throwing Eilis a look. Miss Fortini notes FATHER FLOOD (CONT’D) I'd been led to believe that you didn’t need looking after. Franco Bartocci said you were doing great here. Ma Kehoe said you were the nicest lodger she'd ever had... Eilis smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Ma Kehoe! Miss Fortini, observing the slight uplift in Eilis’s mood slips out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: Don’t ever call her that to her face. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 26.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I'd forgotten just how bad it feels to be away from home. Do you spend every second thinking about giving up here and going back? Eilis nods vehemently. FATHER FLOOD (CONT’D) But at the same time, you know you can’t, because there’s nothing there. It would be the end of you. She says nothing. FATHER FLOOD (CONT’D) I have enrolled you in a night class. For book-keeping. Brooklyn College, the best there is. It will be three nights a week, but you'll get a good qualification at the end of it. And I’ve paid your tuition for the first semester. Eilis looks at him wonderingly.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Why? Father Flood smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: “Why?” Not, “Thank you”? Eilis looks stricken.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Thank you. But...Why? Father Flood thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: I was amazed that someone as clever as you couldn’t find proper work. I have been here too long: I forget what it’s like in Ireland. So when your sister wrote to me about you, I said that the Church would try to help. Anyway, we need Irish girls in Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I wish I could stop feeling that I want to be an Irish girl in Ireland. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 27.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: All I can say is that it will pass. Homesickness is like most sicknesses. It will make you feel wretched, and then it will move on to somebody else. Eilis thinks about this, and nods decisively. 4l INT. BROOKLYN COLLEGE. NIGHT 41 Eilis listening to a lecture in her night class. She's absorbed, anxious, furiously taking notes. She is the onl woman in the class; the men are all either Jewish or Ital The lecturer, MR ROSENBLUM, is in his forties, bespectacl and wearing a skull-cap. He’s animated by his subject, bu it’s clear that most of the class are despairingly perple

dialogues.speaker: MR ROSENBLUM
dialogues.text: Now, Taylor versus Standard Gas Co is one of the most important corporate cases decided in the Supreme Court in the last twenty years. This was the case responsible for the Deep Rock doctrine, so it’s maybe the biggest milestone in parent-subsidiary law. In public utility integration proceedings alone... He stops, looks at his students, to emphasise the point h making. MR ROSENBLUM (CONT’D) .. literally thousands of investors may be affected by its application. We see a close-up of Eilis’s pad: she’s underlining the w ‘literally thousands’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis is sitting outside the lecture room on a wooden ben while the other students stretch their limbs and yawn. Sh eating a sandwich. A young Jewish man is sitting a few fe away from her, doing the same thing. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Did you understand any of that? I mean, a single word? Eilis, eating, shakes her head, covers her mouth with her hands, laughs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 43 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 28.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: He’s not even reading from a book. He just knows all this. He stands up.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Let’s hope the next hour is easier. He smiles at her and goes back into the hall as Eilis cra the last remaining crust into her mouth. INT. DINING ROOM, MRS. KEHOE’S HOUSE. EVENING 43 Dinner time, all the girls and their landlady, the usual formation. Miss McAdam, the battle-axe from Belfast, is holding forth.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MCADAM
dialogues.text: One of the things that ruins Christmas in America is the turkey. It all tastes of sawdust.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: So that’s one cheese sandwich for Miss McAdam, and extra turkey for everyone else. The girls snigger; Diana brays.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ladies, please. Eilis, Father Flood told me about your Christmas plans.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Oh, you’re not serving lunch to the old fellas who’ve got nowhere to go, are you? He asks us every year, and we always say no.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: You're a saint, Eilis. They smell awful.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Sheila knows how they smell because that’s where she goes husband- hunting. Diana brays again.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: As I cannot stand to hear Diana laugh again, I would appreciate it if you kept your witticisms to yourself, Patty. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 44 45 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 29.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a marvellous thing you’re doing, Eilis. A Christian thing. I wish there were more like you. I’1l be doing some of the cooking myself. Silence falls around the table. The other girls look at Eilis, some pityingly, some clearly irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a bright, cold Christmas morning. Mrs Kehoe and Eili are on their way to Father Flood’s lunch. They’re both carrying big bags of potatoes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: I know how you’re feeling, Eilis. The first Christmas away is hard for all my girls, but there’s nothing I can do. All I can say is that the next one won’t be as bad. Eilis cannot afford to think that far ahead, and in any c there is little consolation in Mrs Kehoe’s words.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (quiet) No. I suppose not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall is old, and shabby, but it has been decorated wi paper streamers, and it looks cheery and welcoming. There several long trestle tables, each the length of the hall. Eilis and many other women, including Mrs Kehoe, all wear paper hats, are laying the tables. Father Flood looks on anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: I think we will have to open the doors, ready or not. Maureen? A woman standing near the large double doors unbolts them opens them. Immediately, old, shabby, tubercular men star pour through the door in an apparently never-ending strea It is a haunting, moving sight: the lost, the lonely and defeated. Eilis forgets herself and stares at them.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (to Father Flood) How many are we expecting?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: There were two hundred last year. There may be more this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 30.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Eilis and Father Flood watch as the men are chivvied alon one of the long trestle tables. Almost immediately they a served with soup and stout. FATHER FLOOD (CONT’D) All Irish. And all Irish men, more or less. The occasional couple, when the woman is too old to cook.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Why don’t they go home?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: If there’s nothing at home for a young clever girl such as yourself, there’s nothing at home for men like these. Some of them have been here nearly fifty years and have lost touch with everyone. These are the men who built the tunnels and the bridges and the highways. God alone knows what they live on now. Eilis becomes fixated by one particular man. He is wearin old brown coat and a scarf, and his cap almost obscures h face. She looks as though she’s seen a ghost. She puts he hand to her mouth in shock. FATHER FLOOD (CONT’D) Don’t tell me you know someone here. Eilis can’t speak for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: My da.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: I was told that your father had passed away. Eilis recovers herself.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes. He did. Four years ago. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: I understand. Christmas lunch in the Parish Hall... It’s like seeing faces in the fire. It’s happened to me. I have seen men from my childhood who must have been dead thirty years or more. Which one? Eilis points at the man in the brown coat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 31.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FATHER FLOOD (CONT’D) Ah. Frankie Doran. He’s not your father.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Do you know everyone here?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: No. But I know him. You’ll see why later. Later. The room is filled with smoke and conversation and laughter. The tables are being cleared away, and bottles brown carrier bags are being passed around. In a corner o the room, two men are playing fiddles and another a small accordion. Father Flood pulls out a chair, stands on it a clears his throat. Slowly, the room falls silent.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: I don’t want to interrupt the proceedings, but I’m sure you'd like to show your appreciation to all the ladies here for their hard day’s work. Father Flood leads the applause. Some of the men are applauding in Eilis’s direction - she’s the youngest help in the room - and she blushes, smiles, looks down at her feet.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: And by way of a thank you present... As many of you know, there’s a great singer in the room today, and perhaps he can be persuaded to entertain us all. Frankie? The man in the brown coat gets to his feet and starts to in Irish. The musicians in the corner join in, tentativel first, but then with confidence and sympathy. He sings th slow, mournful ballad beautifully, and the smoke and squa of the room, the poverty of the diners, become beautiful The haunting music carries on over the following montage:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men, both in their sixties, are swinging punches at e other. Some of the men watch on amused; Father Flood and couple of the others try to separate them.  47 48 49 50 51 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is nearly empty. Father Flood, Eilis and the oth ladies are trying to rouse some of the casualties of the lunch; it’s like a battlefield. One or two of the men are lying in pools of their own urine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis steps out into a blizzard. There is a man sitting against the wall, asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis making her way through the deserted streets, alone, wind and snow cutting through her. Montage and music end. INT. HALLWAY, MRS. KEHOE’S HOUSE. NIGHT 50 Eilis enters Mrs Kehoe’s house, shakes herself off, takes her coat. We can hear, from upstairs, the peals of laught and tipsy shrieks of the other lodgers. Mrs Kehoe emerges from the front room.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: Would you like to come into the front room for a glass of something? You've earned it.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Thank you. INT. FRONT ROOM, MRS KEHOE’S HOUSE. NIGHT 51 The room is large, and surprisingly well-furnished: old r heavy, comfortable-looking furniture, dark pictures in go frames. There is an old gramophone and a wireless in one corner of the room, and a roaring fire in the hearth. Eil takes it all in while Mrs Kehoe pours her a glass of sher

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: You survived.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Oh, it wasn’t so bad. Mrs Kehoe gives her the sherry and they sit down.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Happy Christmas. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 33.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: Cheers. They sip their drinks ruminatively.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miss McAdam is leaving us. She is going to live with her sister in Manhattan.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: She has the best room in the house. The basement. It’s the biggest and the warmest and the quietest and the best-appointed, and it has its own entrance. Eilis doesn’t say anything, but she knows what’s coming.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: I can only let a certain kind of girl stay there, do you see? Eilis nods, while suppressing a smile. Mrs Kehoe notices amusement.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: Oh, and I’m not talking about looks, here. (Beat) Although I will admit that God gave Miss McAdam an advantage, when I had to think about who I could trust to live down there. You're a pretty girl, Eilis, but you’re sensible. So. You're having the room and that’s that. If you’re working tomorrow, you can pack tonight, and I’1l have your things moved in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Will the other girls not mind?

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: (with satisfaction) Oh, I expect so. What don’t they mind? She drains her sherry.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s been a long day. Eilis realises this is her cue to leave. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 51 52 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 34.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs Kehoe. She puts her sherry down and leaves the room, leaving Mrs Kehoe staring into the fire. INT. DINING ROOM, MRS. KEHOE’S HOUSE. EVENING 52 There has been a significant change at the dinner table: DOLORES, an Irish country girl - red hair, freckles, slow the uptake - has replaced Miss McAdam. There is an atmosp around the table that is new - the teasing and occasional outbreaks of bitchiness have been replaced by a sullen an resentful silence. It becomes clear that the ill-will is directed at the newcomer. Mrs Kehoe attempts to change the atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: Girls, you'll take Dolores to the dance with you on Saturday night, won’t you?

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: (delighted) There’s a dance?

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: Down at the parish hall. Father Flood doesn’t think there’s enough for you girls to do at the weekends.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Oh, there’s plenty for us to do. He just doesn’t want us doing it. Laughter around the table.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: There'll be no alcohol, but you can have fun without it.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (with obvious insincerity) Oh, Patty and I aren’t going this week. We're... going to see a movie instead. Eilis watches the dynamic carefully. She doesn’t want to involved.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: Well, I’m sure Dolores would enjoy a movie just as well. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 53 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 35.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: I would, very much. There are so many more movies here in New York than in Cavan.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s surprising, isn’t it? You’d think it would be the other way around. Patty sniggers. Diana gives one of her awful laughs. The dynamic of the group has clearly changed, with the advent Dolores: the relationship between Patty/Diana and Sheila less adversarial.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Of course, you’d be welcome to join us, Dolores. So long as you don’t mind being a gooseberry.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: Ah, so you both miraculously found boyfriends over the last couple of days, did you? Well, I hope you have more luck with these than you did with the last few. Sheila cannot resist a smile of satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: Will you be going, Eilis?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes, Mrs Kehoe.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: Well, you can look after Dolores, then.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Of course. INT. BEDROOM, MRS KEHOE’S HOUSE. NIGHT 53 Eilis is writing a letter in her new bedroom. It is so mu bigger and nicer than her previous room - it has a fire, rocking chair, rugs on the floor, and a desk, at which sh sitting. She has photographs of Rose and her mother up on mantelpiece. Suddenly there is a knock on the door. Eilis walks over and opens it - Patty and Diana are standing th

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (whispering) We need to talk to you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 54 55 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 36.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: What is it now? She pointedly doesn’t ask them in.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: It’s that Dolores. She’s a scrubber. Diana starts to laugh, and Patty claps a hand over her mo

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: It’s true. She cleans houses. We can’t have her at the table with us. We’re shopgirls and stenographers, not scrubbers.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m trying to study. She begins to close the door in their faces.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: A scrubber, from Cavan, living under... Eilis closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: +-.our roof?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores and Eilis are queueing to get into the dance. We' seen this before, back in Ireland, with Eilis and Nancy. Dolores is no Nancy. She has made a huge and grotesquely misplaced effort for the dance. She’s wearing a cheap lea jacket, a frilly white blouse and white skirt, black stockings and garish bright red lipstick. Eilis’s discomf is acute. And the surroundings are different, too. A group of Afric American men are sitting on steps nearby, playing a game dice; two men wearing yarmulkes walk through the queue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, however, Ireland has been successfully recreated: there’s the non-alcoholic bar, the nearly empty dance-flo the Irish musicians. Eilis is sitting next to Dolores on wooden bench, watching the dancing. Eilis looks bored and unhappy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 37.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: God, there’s nobody here. How are we supposed to get a fella if there’s nobody here?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I expect most people will come after nine.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: People? Or fellas?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Some of the people will be fellas.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: I'd love to meet a fella. Eilis closes her eyes despairingly.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Have you had an American fella? Are they different? Eilis ignores her.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: (twittering, in a rush) My aunt went with an American fella once, in London, after the war. She said he was different. I’ve always wondered what she meant. I wish she'd told me.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (dry) I don’t suppose it was anything terribly complicated. Eilis shuffles down the bench a little way. Suddenly the doors burst open and a group of people come in - mostly y women, but a couple of young men, too. Patty and Diana, dressed up to the nines, are among them. Immediately the atmosphere in the hall changes. More people start to danc there’s more laughter and enjoyment.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: They came! The liars! Eilis ignores her again. Dolores shuffles up to her on th bench. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 55 56 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 38.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Did you see? What a pair of bitches. That’s what the old woman called them. She said they were all bitches, apart from you. Eilis has had enough. She has had enough of Dolores; she had enough of being the kind of person who will look afte Dolores. She hesitates for a moment, then stands up and g to talk to Patty and Diana.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: (recognising the symbolism of the moment, and amused) Well, hello.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Hello. It’s good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: I can see why. I don’t know what you looked like, sitting there, but you sure didn’t look like you were having a good time. Patty appraises her.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the reflection of the girls in the mirror as Patty fiddles with Eilis’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: I know. She rummages around in her handbag and pulls out a couple hair-grips. She uses them to put Eilis’s hair up for her.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: There. That’s better. Now you don’t look like you've just come in from milking the cows.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Is that what I looked like?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Just a bit. Nice clean cows. Let’s go.  57 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis is standing with Patty and a group of her friends, including a young man with heavily oiled hair who is teac Eilis the steps to the dance that is currently happening the dance floor. She is slightly distracted by a young ma staring at her and smiling, a little distance away. This TONY - dark, attractive, white teeth, muscular. She ignor him and carries on with her lesson. When she looks back, still staring, still smiling.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN WITH OILY HAIR
dialogues.text: (shouting over the music) Maybe we could have a dance later?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN WITH OILY HAIR
dialogues.text: A dance? Later?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Oh. Sure. He smiles and leads Patty onto the dance-floor, flirtatio enough to suggest that it was Patty he was interested in the time. The moment he’s gone, Tony makes a move.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Are you here with that guy? The one who was teaching you to dance? Unlike just about every other man at the dance, Tony is American.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So would you dance with me?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m not sure he taught me anything.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter. The secret is to look as though you know what you’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Ah. I wish someone had told me that years ago. He leads her into the middle of the other dancing couples and they start trying to pick up the steps. It is apparen that Tony can dance, but he doesn’t want to show Eilis up he assumes her levels of incompetence and uncertainty. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 40.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Later. Tony and Eilis are dancing cheek-to-cheek - not smooching, but clearly relaxed in each other’s company. O Tony's shoulder, Eilis catches Patty’s eye. Patty makes a so face. Eilis ignores her.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Where do you live? Eilis pauses, and then decides it’s OK to tell him.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Clinton Street.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah? That’s on my way home. Can I walk you?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m going to say yes, then I’m going to tell you why. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So I don’t get the wrong idea? Eilis pauses again. It wouldn’t be the wrong idea. It jus wouldn’t be the only idea.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I suppose so. Is there a girl ina leather jacket sitting on her own on the bench over there? Tony moves so that he can look discreetly. The camera pic out Dolores, sitting on her own, picking at her fingernai

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (incredulously) You don’t know her?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I do. She lives in my boarding house, and she’s awful. If I leave with you, I’m sure she’d understand. You'd be rescuing me.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I get it. Tony smiles a lot, winningly and unaffectedly.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: She‘ll be OK, won’t she?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Sure she will.  58 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis and Tony walking through the dark streets of Brookl huddled against each other for warmth. They walk in silen and then Tony blurts out

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m not Irish.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: You don’t sound Irish.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I need to make this clear: no part of me is Irish. I don’t have Irish parents or grandparents or anything. I’m Italian. My parents are, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: So what were you doing at an Irish dance? Don’t the Italians have dances?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah. And I wouldn’t want to take you to one. They behave like Italians all night.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: And what does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh, you know.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (mumb1ly ) Hands.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Too many of them?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I think it could seem that way, if you were a girl. Listen, I want everything to be out in the open. I came to the Irish dance because I really like Irish girls.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: And I was the only one that would dance with you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 59 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 42.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh, no, it wasn’t...

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Oh, so you danced with loads of others? Eilis is teasing him, and Tony knows it, but he’s not as quick as she is. He tries to formulate a response, gives grins again. They arrive at Mrs Kehoe’s house.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: This is me.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Can I take you next week? Maybe get something to eat first?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I'd like that. Good night. She smiles warmly at him, and goes into the house without kissing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis and Tony getting something to eat first, before the dance. They are eating in a cheap diner, with formica-top tables. They’re waiting for their food.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So...What do you do when you’re not working? She thinks.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Well. There’s school. Just, you know. .Brooklyn College. I’m studying book-keeping.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You want to be a book-keeper?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I want to be an accountant one day. But, yes, book-keeping first.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Wow. Is it difficult?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m talking too much. Tell me about plumbing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 60 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 43.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You know enough about plumbing already.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I don’t know anything.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You know that taps drip and toilets get blocked and that’s all you need to know. I don’t know anything about book-keeping. Suddenly it is as if Eilis has been switched on, and the following comes out in an unstoppable, unbroken stream.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: There’s a lot to it. There’s all the maths, of course, but that’s not so complicated. The double- entry system, that takes a while to get used to. And we study company law, too, and that terrifies me.(Fades) So we had to read about an insurance company that went bankrupt in the 1930s, and all the, the legal issues that... Later. Tony is finishing off his food and listening. Eili food goes untouched, although several times her loaded fo almost makes it to her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (her voice fading in) ...She plays golf, and she’s really good at it. And if she’d been at the dance last Saturday, then I don’t think you'd have looked at me twice, because Rose is beautiful. Tony has finished - his plate is clean.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m worried you haven't eaten anything.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (smiling) Too busy talking. INT. DINING ROOM, MRS. KEHOE’S HOUSE. EVENING 60 The girls eating their supper in a mysterious silence. Pa Diana and Sheila are finding it hard not to giggle. Mrs K puts down her knife and fork in disgust. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: What is the matter with you girls now?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Nothing the matter with us, Mrs Kehoe. She looks steadily at Eilis.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: Is this all because Eilis has found herself a young man?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (mock-surprised) Eilis’s got herself a young man? We didn’t know. She won’t say anything about him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: And why should she, to you awful gossip-mongers? Anyway, I met him on Saturday night when he called for Eilis, and he’s a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Well, will you tell us what you know about him, Mrs Kehoe? We're starving here. We know that he’s quite nice-looking.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: I didn’t like his shoes much.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: What on earth is wrong with his shoes?

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: They were a funny colour.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: I‘1l tell you this much: I am going to ask Father Flood to preach a sermon on the dangers of giddiness. I now see that giddiness is the eighth deadly sin. A giddy girl is every bit as evil as a slothful man, and the noise she makes is a lot worse. Now, enough. 61 INT. BARTOCCI’S. DAY
60 61 The shop is quiet. Dorothy and Eilis are unpacking boxes putting garments out on shelves. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 45.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: You know what I hate about the end of winter? Now it all starts again with the swimsuits. We’re gonna spend hours and hours talking about one stupid item of clothing with a woman who’s so afraid of what she looks like. But in the winter she'll splash thirty-five dollars on a coat in the blink... Dorothy is staring into a box she has just opened.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I don’t believe it. Eilis looks at her quizzically.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna talk to Miss Fortini about this. She marches off. Eilis peers into the box. It contains Re Fox stockings. She takes a packet out and examines it. Later. Miss Fortini comes over to speak to Eilis. She’s angry.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: Eilis, I want you to know that Dorothy has left our employment. Eilis looks at her wonderingly.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: As of today. She’s clearing her locker. (Beat) Listen. Brooklyn is changing, and we have to change with it. Eilis nods, even though she is mystified by the series of apparent non-sequiturs - the stockings, Dorothy, the spee

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: Our old customers are moving out to Long Island and we can’t follow them, so we need new customers every week. Which means we welcome every single person who comes into this store. They all have money to spend. Remember that.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I will. Eilis shows Miss Fortini the Red Fox stockings. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61 62 63 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 46.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Should I put these out on the shelves?

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course. Do you understand anything I’ve been saying? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No, Miss Fortini.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: (sighing) Red Fox stockings are specially designed for Negro customers. Dorothy was unhappy about us selling them. I asked her to leave. Are you unhappy?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No, Miss Fortini.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: Good. Quickly, now. Miss Fortini walks off. Eilis immediately turns her atten to the stockings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis comes out of her classroom with a couple of other students, books under her arm, and begins to walk down th stairs. In the entrance hall she can see Tony, looking ar anxiously, clearly worried about missing her. She stops - clearly isn’t expecting to see him. She watches him for a moment - he doesn’t see her - and she takes in his open f his vulnerability... He sees her and his face breaks out a radiant and relieved smile. She smiles back, and walks the remaining steps towards him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: All I want to do is travel home with you. No drink, no food, no nothing. I know you have to study, and get some sleep. I’1l take you to your house and then say goodnight. Otherwise it’s too long to wait. He says this with such unaffected simplicity that it’s impossible not to love him. Eilis smiles her assent.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 63
dialogues.text: 64 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis and Tony sitting side-by-side on the half empty tro car.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I want to ask you something. And you're gonna say, oh, it’s too soon, I don’t really know him well enough, we've only been out a couple times... Eilis pantomimes alarm. She looks

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s nothing so bad. But it is something that most guys...

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (laughing) Please just ask. You’re beginning to terrify me.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh. Sure. Will you come for dinner and meet my family sometime?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (laughing) That’s it? I’d love to.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You like Italian food?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’ve never eaten it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Really? They don’t have it in Ireland?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Maybe in Dublin. Not in my town.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It’s the best food in the world.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Well, why would I not like it?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You're in a good mood, right? at him.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes. Why? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 64 65 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It’s just... I like how you’re being, I don’t know the word. When you go along with everything.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Amenable?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (delighted with this addition to his vocabulary) Yeah. Amenable. OK, so while you’re being amenable..Can we go see a movie this week? When you’re not at night classes? And if the date goes well, can we see a movie next week, too?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I‘1l sign up for two movies.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes. Even if the first date is a disaster, I'll give it another chance. Tony’s smile couldn’t be any broader. INT. BARTOCCI’S. DAY 48. 64 65 Eilis, in her uniform, serving a customer. Off to the sid Miss Fortini is watching her at work. We’ve seen this bef but this time, Eilis is unaware of Miss Fortini’s scrutin She's absorbed in her work, chatting to the customer, a y woman in her thirties.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: It certainly feels like it, but this is my first year, so I don’t know how to judge.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Well, congratulations. You survived your first New York winter.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Oh, it wasn’t so bad.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Really? It’s colder in Ireland? (CONTINUED)
