dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 49,

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Oh, no. It’s colder here.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Over here, that’s how we judge the winter. On how cold it is. The cylindrical tube shoots back to Eilis’s counter, and takes out the receipt and the change and hands it to the customer.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: But you have heating. Heating everywhere. You’re only cold outside.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: I guess that’s true. Thanks for your help. The customer walks away, and Miss Fortini comes over.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: Eilis! You’re like a different person! Where did that miserable little mouse go? Eilis smiles and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: The homesickness has gone? Eilis looks startled, as if she has only just realised.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: How did you do it? Maybe I can pass some advice on to the next poor girl who feels that way. Eilis’s face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I...I met somebody. An Italian fella.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: (mock despondent) Oh, no. Well, I’m not passing that on. I’d rather have them homesick than heartbroken. Does he talk about baseball all the time? Or his mother? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 66 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 50.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: Then keep him. There isn’t another Italian man like him in New York. She smiles at Eilis and moves on. INT. DINING ROOM, MRS KEHOE’S HOUSE. NIGHT 66 Eilis is sitting at the kitchen table with a bowl of spaghetti in front of her. There is a fork and spoon on either side of the bowl. Opposite her are Patty and Diana Eilis goes to pick up the cutlery. Diana gestures at her stop.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Hold it. Remember You’re getting off easy, because we haven’t got sauce.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Yeah. You have to remember that the sauce flies everywhere, so take it slowly.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I’m gonna say “Splash” every time I see problems.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Good idea.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (smiling) Can I start now?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY DIANA
dialogues.text: Go. Yep. They watch intently as Eilis grapples with the twirling. three girls are staring at the spaghetti, lost in concentration. Eilis allows the spaghetti to fall off the fork and back into the plate.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (loudly)

dialogues.speaker: SPLASH
dialogues.text: Eilis and Patty jump and then giggle nervously.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You just splashed his mother, and his father, and the walls... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 69A
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 51.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Eilis makes a despairing face.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Let’s go again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spring day in Ireland. Rose is sitting by the river, reading one of Eilis’s letters and eating an apple.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I suppose the most important news is that I have a boyfriend. He isn’t as important as Bartocci’s and my night classes, I know that. But I want to tell you everything that’s going on. Please don’t mention it to Mummy, though. You know what she’s like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis and Tony have just been to see ‘Singin’ In The Rain They emerge from the cinema radiant; Tony in particular h clearly loved the film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony is earnestly trying out some of Gene Kelly’s dance m while Eilis watches.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He’s decent and kind, and he has a job, and he works hard. We go to the cinema on Wednesdays and he takes me to Father Flood’s dance on Saturdays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose reading avidly.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I think of you and Mother every single day. But Tony has helped me to feel that I have a life here. I didn’t have, before I met him. My body was here, but my life was back in Ireland, with you. Now it is halfway across the sea. So, that’s something, isn’t it?  70 71 72 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis and Tony are climbing the stairs to Tony’s apartmen Tony is talking animatedly and a little nervously.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh and I’d better warn you about Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: He’s the little one.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah. He’s eight going on eighteen. He’s nice and he’s smart, but he’s been talking and talking about all the things he’s going to say to you.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: What sort of things?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: We don’t know. Could be anything. I tried to pay him money to go out and play ball with his friends, and my dad has threatened him, but I think he’s looking forward to causing trouble so much that he’1l happily take a beating. This is us here.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Ready? Eilis nods. He’s making her nervous. INT. TONY’S APARTMENT. NIGHT 72 Tony’s apartment is tiny, and Eilis appears somewhat wedg in around the dinner table. Tony has two older brothers, Laurenzio and Maurizio, as well as kid brother Frankie. H mother and father are young - much younger than Eilis’s mother. The atmosphere around the table is polite and warm. It’s a question of Eilis having to impress the Fiorello family they want to impress her, too, or at least the adults do. They understand that she is important to Tony, and Tony i important to them. Eilis is doing her best with her spaghetti, which is cove in a rich, deep red sauce. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 53.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FIORELLO
dialogues.text: Hey, how did you learn to eat spaghetti like that? Eilis pauses before confessing.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I've been taking lessons. The family look at her, delighted.

dialogues.speaker: LAURENZIO
dialogues.text: Lessons? Like, in a class? You can do that? Maybe I could teach it.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No, no. Diana, who lives in the boarding house with me... She cooked me some spaghetti and made me try and eat it without making a mess.

dialogues.speaker: MR FIORELLO
dialogues.text: What do you eat in Ireland? Just Irish stew?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Not just. We...

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: So first of all I should say that we don’t like Irish people. There are general cries of outrage around the table. Maurizio, who is sitting next to him, cuffs him on the to his head.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: (outraged) We don’t! That is a well known fact! A big gang of Irish beat Maurizio up and he had to have stitches. And because all the cops round here are Irish, nobody did anything about it. Eilis looks at Maurizio for confirmation. He looks embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: MAURIZIO
dialogues.text: There are probably two sides to it. I might have said something I shouldn't, I can’t remember now.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: No, because they beat you up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 54.

dialogues.speaker: MAURIZIO
dialogues.text: Anyway, they probably weren’t all Irish.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: They just had red hair and big legs. Mr Fiorello stands up and leads Frankie away from the tab and out the door by his ear.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: All I can say in his defence is that he’s the only one of us who’ll get a college education.

dialogues.speaker: LAURENZIO
dialogues.text: If he keeps his mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FIORELLO
dialogues.text: Tony tells me you go to college.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Oh, just night classes. I want to be a book-keeper. I like working in the shop well enough, but I don’t want to be there forever. Frankie re-enters the room, with his father right behind.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: (parrot-fashion) sorry, Eilis. I’m an idiot. Oh, a rude idiot. I'm I'm His brothers applaud and laugh. Frankie makes a face at t and sits down at the table. Later. They are eating scallopini, on their own, with no vegetables, Italian-style.

dialogues.speaker: MAURIZIO
dialogues.text: So has Tony offered to take you to Ebbett’s Field when the season starts?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (to Tony) You like baseball? More laughter around the table.

dialogues.speaker: MAURIZIO
dialogues.text: (incredulous ) He never mentioned the Dodgers? Not even once? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 73 74 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 55.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You know why? Too much of this. He makes a lewd kissing noise. Tony rolls his eyes. Eilis the good grace to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: LAURENZIO
dialogues.text: Anyway, you'll have to go to Ebbett’s Field if you want to see him in the summer.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: They're that important to you?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Put it this way. If our kids end up supporting the Yankees or the Giants, it would break my heart. The family laughs, but Eilis can only manage a small smil “Our kids”? Suddenly Eilis sees that their future is all mapped out, as far as Tony and his family are concerned. Frankie is watching her complicated reaction.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: She's not laughing, Tony. I think it’s too late. She’s a Yanks fan. More laughter. But Tony is watching her carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony and Eilis outside Mrs Kehoe’s. Tony comes in close t Eilis, holds her, kisses her cheek. Eilis is stiff, a lit afraid.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (softly) I love you. Eilis stays in the embrace a moment longer, then pulls aw

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I..Thank you for the evening. It was lovely. She walks down the path towards her house, leaving Tony staring wistfully after her. INT. BATHROOM, MRS. KEHOE’S HOUSE. NIGHT 74 Eilis in the bathroom in her dressing gown, cleaning her teeth. She stops, and looks at herself in the mirror - ma trying to imagine herself older, married, a mother, an American. The bathroom door rattles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 56.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sorry! Eilis is pulled out of the reverie and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I'd finished. (Beat, and then, tentatively) Sheila... Can I ask you something? Why aren’t you married?

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Because my husband met somebody else and left me.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Oh. I’m sorry. Sheila shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: And...Well, would you get married again?

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Has someone asked you?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: I won’t ask what that means. Would I get married again? No. I want to be waiting outside the bathroom of my boarding-house forever. Eilis doesn’t know how to take this.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Of course I do. That’s why I go to that wretched dance every week. I want to be waiting outside my own bathroom. (Beat) While some bad- tempered fella with hair growing out of his ears reads the newspaper on the toilet. And then I'1l wish I was back here, talking to you. She laughs despairingly, and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis emerges from her class, starts to walk down the sta and stops, scanning the entrance hall. Tony isn’t there. walks down the stairs slowly, still looking around. She s in the entrance hall and waits for a moment.  76 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis stands waiting outside, looking up and down the str for Tony. No sign. She gives up and starts to walk up the street.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Eilis! She looks around. Tony is on the other side of the street breathless and smiling. Eilis smiles broadly back, with visible relief.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I thought you weren’t coming.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I thought you’d think that. That’s why I wanted to be here no matter what.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I need to say something to you. Tony’s face falls. He thinks he knows what’s coming.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Can you... Can we talk about something else until we get to Mrs Kehoe's?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: It’s not...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Please? They start to walk along the street together.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So. Ten minutes before I’m supposed to meet you and I’m standing ankle- deep in sewage that’s pouring through this old lady’s ceiling. Eilis looks at his shoes, reflexively.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Even if you were thinking of inviting me in for a coffee, I'd have to say no, for your sake. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 58.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: So how did you fix it in ten minutes?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I didn’t. I spent the whole ten minutes explaining to the old lady that I had to be somewhere and I'd be back. She didn’t want to let me go.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: So the sewage is still pouring through the ceiling? Tony shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh, what’s the difference between six inches of sewage and a foot? Eilis laughs. Tony looks at her anxiously - is she really going to break off their relationship? Eilis stops.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Let me say what I want to say. I think... I think you’ll... I don’t think you'll mind. Tony takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: You remember that after I had dinner at your house, you told me that you loved me. Tony nods, sombre and nervous.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Well, I didn’t really know what to say. But I know what to say now. I have thought about you and I like you, and I like seeing you, and maybe I feel the same way. So the next time you tell me you love me, if there is a next time, I’11..1’11 say I love you too.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (excited) Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 77 78 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 59.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Holy shit! Excuse my language, but I thought we were going to have a different kind of talk. You mean it?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So why aren’t you smiling? She flashes him a quick, forced smile.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Can I go home now?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You love me?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes. But don’t ask me anything else, and don’t talk about our kids being Dodgers fans.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (laughing) You want kids who like the Yankees?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Tony, please don’t push me.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (suddenly sober) All right. I’m sorry. They walk on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis is walking down a Brooklyn street on an early summe evening, holding an envelope. The trees are green, childr are playing in the street, the last of the daylight is glinting off the roofs. Eilis takes it all in; she’s happ She reaches Father Flood’s parish house and knocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Flood is scanning the letter contained in the enve while Eilis watches him intently. He hands it back to her thoughtfully. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 60.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: Well. You’re marvellous. That’s all I have to say. And it looks to me as though you didn’t just pass those exams. You, you flew through them. Eilis smiles shyly.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: Most people who come and visit me without notice are in trouble, of some kind or another. I can’t remember the last time anyone came here with good news.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I have saved some money. I’1l be able to pay next year’s tuition and pay you back for last year.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: One of my parishioners paid. He needed to do something for mankind, and I won’t tell you why. He’s not out of the woods yet, either, so he can cough up for next year, too.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I'd love to know what sort of woods he’s in.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: Yes, well you won’t hear it from me. How's Tony? Eilis looks at him, surprised to be asked.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: He’s well. Thank you for asking.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: He’s a solid man. Qualifications and a boyfriend, Eilis. You’re not the miserable young girl who wanted to go home last winter.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: That seems like years ago. 79 INT. DINING ROOM, MRS KEHOE’S HOUSE. EVENING 79 The girls and Mrs Kehoe at the end of their evening meal. They are collecting plates and putting crockery by the si ready for washing up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 61.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Eilis puts fresh bowls and spoons down on the table. Mrs Kehoe comes to the table with a large pie on a plate.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: I think this is the first time that any girl of mine has passed an exam while living here, so I bought us a treat. There are murmurs of appreciation. Mrs Kehoe sits down at table and starts cutting the pie into slices and putting slices into bowls.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Have you told Tony, Eilis?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: And is he taking you out to celebrate?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: We're going to Coney Island at the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: (drily) Oh, boy.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You have a bathing costume?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No. I was going to get one at...

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Do you have sunglasses?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (increasingly alarmed) No.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: You need sunglasses. I read that if you don’t have them on the beach this year people will talk about you.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: (witheringly) And what will they say, exactly, Sheila? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 62.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sheila blushes.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: (seriously) That's the thing, Mrs Kehoe. You'd never know, because they’d never say it to your face. Mrs Kehoe rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: Diana’s right, though, Eilis. You need to think carefully about your costume. It’s the most Tony will ever have seen of you. You don’t want to put him off. 80 INT. BARTOCCI’S. DAY 80 Eilis in her lunch hour, choosing a one-piece bathing sui from the racks in front of her. She picks out a black one a pink one, and goes off towards the dressing-rooms. As i from nowhere, Miss Fortini appears.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: Are you going to the beach?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Fortini. To Coney Island. With Tony.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: Well, I know he’s a saint, this Tony, but every Italian man cares about how his girlfriend looks in her bathing suit. I’d better help you.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis walks into one of the cubicles, but before she can the curtain across, Miss Fortini is in the cubicle with h There’s hardly room for the two of them. Eilis starts to undressed, as modestly as she can in the peculiar circumstances. Miss Fortini watches her, matter-of-factly Later. Eilis is wearing the black suit. Miss Fortini look her thoughtfully, and then reaches forward to pull down t fabric at the top of Eilis’s thigh. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 81 82 83 84 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 63.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: You'll have to shave down here. I'll give you a razor that will do the trick. She then reaches round to cup Eilis’s bottom. Eilis is to shocked to say anything.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: You're all right there for the moment. And most Italian men appreciate the fuller figure. But watch yourself, over the summer. She steps back as far as she can and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: The black’s too dark, for your pale skin. Let’s see you in the green. Eilis hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FORTINI
dialogues.text: Quickly now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony and Eilis on the boardwalk at Coney Island. It’s a bright, beautiful day; Eilis is, after all, wearing fashionable sunglasses and a headscarf. They’re both eati cotton candy. They stop and look for a space on the packe beach.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I can see a spot down there that’s probably big enough for one. If we can wedge ourselves in, maybe we can eventually create enough space for two. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 85 86 87 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 64.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We watch as Tony and Eilis make their way down onto the b to become a small and anonymous part of the New York summ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony is holding a towel round Eilis as she struggles in t her bathing costume. He’s looking away, presumably at her request.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me to put my costume on underneath my clothes?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I thought you’d know. She's finished struggling.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m ready. He drops the towel. Eilis stands there in her costume, a little embarrassed. Tony gives a loud and lascivious wolf whistle. Eilis giggles with embarrassment and pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis and Tony in the sea. Eilis swims away from Tony - s a good swimmer - but he swims after her, catches her and draws him to her. He picks her up as she tries to wriggle away, laughing. He pulls her to him and kisses her. She freezes a little and pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (smiling) I’m sorry. What’s a guy supposed to do? She looks at him, and then kisses him deeply. FADE OUT. INT. BARTOCCI’S. DAY 87 Eilis at her counter, serving a customer. Music, somethin ominously melancholic that undercuts the banal pleasantri of Eilis’s letter.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Dear Rose. Thanks for your letter. I was happy to hear about your golf tournament. You must have been really pleased.  88 89 90 91 92 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 65. INT. EILIS’S HOME IN IRELAND. DAY 88 We see Mary knocking on the door of Rose’s bedroom anxiou

dialogues.speaker: EILIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I still miss you and mother, and I think about you every day. INT. ROSE’S BEDROOM. DAY 89 Mary enters the bedroom. Rose is sprawled half out of the bed, her head nearly touching the floor; Mary rushes over her, touches her cheek, starts to weep.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But I think I can say that for the first time since I’ve been in America, I’m really happy. EXT. EILIS’S HOME. STREET. DAY 90 Mary, consoled by a neighbour, watches as Rose’s body, covered by a shroud, is taken to a waiting ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is a lot to do with Tony. He’s kind and seems to care about me. And we have fun, too. INT. DINING ROOM, EILIS’S HOME. DAY 91 Mary sitting on an armchair in her parlour, gripping a handkerchief tightly. The room is filling up with sombre, concerned people who are queuing up to speak to her.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: At the weekend he took me to see the Brooklyn Dodgers, the baseball team he loves. They lost, so he was annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary on her knees in church, while she prays at mass.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But I’ve also started to look for office work, too. I had an interview this week at a textile firm here in Brooklyn.  93 94 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 66. INT. BARTOCCI’S. DAY 93 Eilis looks up, startled, as Miss Fortini and Father Floo approach her counter.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Who'd have thought that there would be two book-keepers in the family? I’1ll soon be able to afford to... Her voice trails off. We can’t hear what Father Flood is saying to her, but she looks stricken. The music fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Flood and Eilis are sitting on two chairs in the middle, knees almost touching. Eilis is staring at the fl in shock; Father Flood is watching her with enormous tenderness and concern.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: It was sudden. I think perhaps she was ill, and she knew she was ill, and she didn’t tell anybody.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: What will happen?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: (softly) What can happen?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: When will they bury her?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Without me.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: Without you. You’re too far away, Eilis. Eilis starts to cry, and becomes almost hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Why did I ever come here? Why did I ever come here?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: Rose wanted a better life for you. She loved how well you were doing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 95 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 67.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: And now I will never see her again. Father Flood doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: That's right, isn’t it, Father? I will never see her again.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: You know that I think you will. And she will be watching over you, every day, for the rest of your life.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I wish I had never left. I wish I had never come over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony and Eilis are sitting in the diner that they use bef the Saturday night dances. They have coffee cups in front them, but they’re not drinking. Tony is quiet, grief-stri for a woman he’s never met.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I keep thinking about what it would be like if one of my brothers died. I'm sorry if that sounds selfish. But it means I can feel what you’re feeling.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I think about it and think about it, and then I forget about it for a moment, and when I remember again it’s as though I’ve just been told. I can’t bear it, Tony.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I wish I could stay with you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: But I’1l see you in the morning. It’s very nice of your family, to come to Mass with me.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: They wouldn’t miss it for anything. I don’t mean that like it sounds. I just mean...

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I know. Thank you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 68.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You want to go home, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes. But I don’t know if I can.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: If it’s money, then we can all help. I mean, the whole family. Eilis blinks back more tears.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: And how would it be for you if I did go home? Tony shrugs, and then says, simply and sincerely

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I'd be afraid, every single day.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Afraid that I wouldn’t come back?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Home is home.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I have a home any more. Tony thinks.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You're not going to work tomorrow, are you?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: After the mass, can I take you somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony and Eilis are standing on a piece of utterly feature and undeveloped land. The wind is blowing, and we can hea seagulls, although there is no view of the sea.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: This is it. He gestures around him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 69.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: We’re going to build five houses here, if we can. Mom and Dad will have one, because Mom has always wanted a house with a back yard. And we’ll sell three. And the other one...My brothers asked me if I wanted it, and I said I did. Tony studies her face intently.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So I guess what I’m saying is, would you like to live here on Long Island? I know it doesn’t look like much right now, but all the land around here has been sold, so we wouldn’t be on our own. And there’d be, there'd be telephone cables and electricity and everything. Eilis laughs.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I would hope so.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: We're going to set up a company, a building company, the three of us, and I’m gonna do the plumbing, and Laurence will do the carpentry, and.. Eilis looks around her, trying to imagine the future that Tony sees. It’s not so hard to do.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Don’t go quiet on me. At least tell me you'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I don’t need to think about it. She holds out her hands, and Tony takes them, and she pul him towards her. The camera pulls back and back until we two tiny figures, on their own, standing in the middle of their own future, of a part of America that doesn’t even exist yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis is sitting in a chair in Father Flood’s office. She nervous and pale. Father Flood is pacing around. They are both watching the telephone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 97 98 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 70.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: I’m sure she won’t be long.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m not sure she even knows where the parish house is.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: Oh, Father Quaid has a car. He was going to collect her and drive her up.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Part of me doesn’t even want to talk to her. My own mother!

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLOOD
dialogues.text: It’s a difficult conversation to be having, Eilis. You wouldn’t be human if you were looking forward to it. The telephone rings. Both of them stare at it for a secon and then Father Flood gestures at Eilis to pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Hello? Mummy? She sounds noticeably more Irish throughout the conversat

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I can’t really hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is in the same situation - in an unfamiliar ecclesiastical office, with a priest watching her with concern. Mary looks so much older than the last time we s her, and completely defeated. What comes out of her mouth cannot reflect the depth of her pain.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well, the rain held off, anyway. Intercut phone conversation.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: That’s good.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And the whole of her golf club came. Every single one of them. We had a real houseful afterwards. Eilis doesn’t say anything. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 99 100 101 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 71.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Are you still there?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: People really loved her, Eilis. Her friends from work, the neighbours, everybody. Eilis is weeping.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Nobody knew what to say to me. Finally, her words reflect how she is feeling.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: When your daddy died, I said to myself that I shouldn’t grieve too much because I had you two. And when you went to America, I told myself the same thing because she was here with me. But everyone’s gone, Eilis. I have nobody. Eilis is weeping so hard that she can’t speak. Father Flo comes up behind her and puts his hand on her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis lying on her bed, staring at the ceiling. She’s sti wearing her coat. She gets up and leaves the room. INT. TONY’S HOUSE. NIGHT 100 Eilis knocks on Tony’s door. It’s late, and the house is dark. Tony opens the door wearing a T-shirt and undershor He’s clearly been asleep.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Come in for a second. I’1l get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony and Eilis walking through the quiet, late night stre Tony holds Eilis to him as close as he can. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 72.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (resigned, sad) I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Just for a month or so. I know it would make her feel a little better. Tony doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Please speak.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Will you marry me before you leave?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: You don’t trust me to come back?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Marry me. Marry me. We don’t have to tell anyone. We can do it quickly, and it will just be between us.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: But why do you want to do it?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (agonised) Because if we don’t, I'll go crazy.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Would a promise not be the same?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: If you can promise, then you can easily do this. Eilis sighs, nods, smiles weakly.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (heartfelt) Thank you. 102 EXT. MRS KEHOE’S HOUSE. NIGHT 102 They have arrived at Eilis’s lodgings. They stand on the sidewalk outside the dark, quiet house and kiss.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Come inside.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Really? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 102 103 104 105 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 73.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She leads him down the little path to her private entranc the basement and unlocks the door. INT. EILIS’S BEDROOM. NIGHT 103 Eilis and Tony enter the basement room. Eilis takes off h coat, and Tony stands there awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So this is it? This is where you live?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes, and if you make one tiny noise she’1ll evict me. Shyly, she walks towards him and kisses him gently. The k becomes more passionate. Eilis pulls his shirt out from h trousers and runs her hands up and down his back. They mo towards the single bed without speaking. Tony lifts Eilis skirt and undoes his trousers and lies down on top of her All the time, there is a sense that Tony is taking his cu from her, that he would stop the moment Eilis expressed a doubt or fear. But she moves out from underneath him and discreetly removes her panties. Tony pulls his trousers o and takes off his boxer shorts. They make love. Eilis tries hard not to panic at the feel of Tony inside her, but she’s clearly shocked by the sensation; meanwhile Tony is much noisier than she would him to be, and that panics her further. Eventually he is still, and he lies on top of her for a moment. A floorboard creaks above their heads. Tony looks up, loo at Eilis.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Oh, there’s no point in worrying now. Stay with me. Tony gets off her, stands up, takes the rest of his cloth off and gets into bed. Eilis hesitates, then starts to unstrap her bra. EXT. MRS KEHOE’S HOUSE. DAY 104 Eilis comes home from work. She pushes at the gate to the basement, but it has been padlocked. INT. DINING ROOM, MRS. KEHOE’S HOUSE. EVENING. 105 Eilis is making herself some scrambled eggs in the kitche for her tea. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 105 106 107 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 74.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mrs Kehoe is sitting at the kitchen table reading the newspaper. There is a frosty silence. Patty comes in and fills the kettle.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KEHOE
dialogues.text: Patty, I’ve put a lock on the basement gate. Just for peace of mind. You never know who might try to get in there. She folds the paper, stands up and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: As God is my witness, I heard nothing last night. Nothing at all. But it sounded lovely. Eilis looks away, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis and Tony walking in to City Hall, hand-in-hand. Bot have bought new suits for the occasion, but they are on t own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis and Tony are in the waiting room in City Hall; ther are a couple of other parties waiting to get married, but they really are parties, with friends and parents and siblings. The group sitting nearest to them contains an e or nine year-old boy, Frankie’s age, who is bored, and getting into trouble with his parents. Tony leaves Eilis sitting on a chair and starts fooling around with the boy they play bat and ball with a rolled-up newspaper and a l plastic ball that the kid has been playing catch with. Th boy’s father comes over.

dialogues.speaker: BOY'S FATHER
dialogues.text: Is he annoying you? Because he was annoying me. The father is Irish.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No, no. I got a brother the exact same age. Hey, are you Irish?

dialogues.speaker: BOY'S FATHER
dialogues.text: (grinning) Is it so obvious? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 75.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m just about to marry an Irish girl, so I guess I notice it more. There are a lot of you in Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: BOY'S FATHER
dialogues.text: Sometimes it seems as though there can’t be anybody left at home. Where’s your girl from?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Enniscorthy, in County Wexford. Have you heard of it? Tony throws the kid a gentle pitch with the ball.

dialogues.speaker: BOY'S FATHER
dialogues.text: I think my wife has family there, but she’s got family everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It’s the same thing with my family. If you believe anything my dad says, the Fiorellos own most of Italy. I don’t understand why we ever left. The other man chuckles. Tony calls over to Eilis.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hey, Eilis. Come here a second. An official from County Hall emerges from an office and addresses the waiting room.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Anthony Fiorello and Eilis Lacey.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Maybe another time.

dialogues.speaker: BOY'S FATHER
dialogues.text: Good luck. Eilis takes his arm. Tony kisses her on her cheek and the walk off to get married. 108 EXT. MRS KEHOE’S HOUSE. NIGHT 108 Tony and Eilis are kissing outside Mrs Kehoe’s. Eilis bre off and looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Will we ever tell our children we did this? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 108 109 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 76.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Maybe we'll save it for some anniversary.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I wonder what they’1l think of it?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: They'll believe that we saw a movie and ate hot dogs. They won’t believe that on our wedding night I dropped you off at Ma Kehoe’s and went home. Eilis smiles and kisses him again. The camera pans back t show the married couple, kissing in the dark with nowhere go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sunny Sunday morning. Eilis is emerging from Mass arm-i arm with Mary. Suddenly we see what we haven’t been able notice before: Eilis has come back from America a differe person. She’s older, and more sophisticated, her clothes better and brighter than those of anyone else from her to her hair-style classier, her skin a different colour. Mar meanwhile, has been aged very quickly by grief and loneliness. Eilis’s emergence into the Sunday morning light is complicated. People are excited to see her, but at the sa time they know they have to be respectful of her recent l Her friend NANCY - Eilis’s age, pretty, bubbly - is, howe just overwhelmed with excitement, and pushes through the emerging congregation to greet her. Eilis breaks into a b smile.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Nancy! In a modern age, or a less buttoned-up culture, they woul fall into each other’s arms and squeal. There is that lev of excitement, but they channel it through the clasping o hands.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You look so glamorous!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (sourly) I told you so. Eilis rolls her eyes at Nancy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 109 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 77.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry about Rose.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It was a beautiful funeral, Mrs Lacey.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: How are you? Nancy wiggles her fingers, and Eilis sees the engagement on her finger.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (excited) No!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I knew. But I wanted to let Nancy tell you herself.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I’m so glad you can come to the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Can I?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Your mother accepted the invitation on your behalf.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: When is it?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: The 27th of August. Eilis’s smile freezes perceptibly.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Will you come out with George and me tomorrow night? Annette wants to see you, too. Eilis looks at Mary for permission.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t mind. I’1l have to find you a key. I don’t want you getting me out of bed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 109 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 78.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We all want to hear what life in New York is like.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I'll try and think of something to say. Nancy rejoins her parents, who are standing a little way away, waiting for her.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m booked to go back to New York on the twenty-first.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (blithe) Oh, you can wait an extra week to see your best friend married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis walking down a path in her local church in Ireland. She's holding a wreath. Close on her hands - she takes he wedding ring out of her pocket, slips it on. She arrives at Rose’s grave. She kneels, places the wreat the grave, stands up. She’s sombre, near tears, but toget

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’ve come home. Just for... An elderly lady is coming down the path. Eilis stops, sel conscious, and waits until she’s walked past.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Just for a month or so. I know mother needed me home. There’s so much to do. Mother wants me to go through all your clothes, and take what I want. I can’t bear to take anything. (Beat) Rose, I got married. I married Tony. Just before I left. Nobody knows, not even Mother. Only you, now. We were married at City Hall, and when I go back we’ll get married properly. I’1ll tell people then. I can’t believe I’m married to someone you will never know. But you’d like him. I know you would. He’s sweet, and funny, and he has these wonderful eyes that.. She stops and sighs heavily. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 110 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 79.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I wish..Oh, I wish everything were different. (Beat) It’s so strange, being in the house without you. Every time I hear even the slightest noise I think it’s you. I pray for you every day. I hope you pray for us. She closes her eyes, momentarily, and then walks away. INT. DINING ROOM, EILIS’S HOUSE. DAY 111 Eilis and Mary, sitting at the table in the front room, plodding through the pile of letters that have to be writ

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So now. She picks up the next one in the pile.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Mrs O’Toole from Cush.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Do we really have to do this? Getting a letter of condolence isn’t like getting a birthday present, is it? What if Mrs O'Toole from Cush writes back to thank you for your thank you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Then I’1l1 thank her.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: And you'd be happy to spend the rest of your life like that?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It’s not as if I have anything else to do. Nor anybody else to talk to. It might as well be Mrs O'Toole from Cush.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (wearily) What do you want me to say? Just at that moment there is the sound of a car horn - tw beeps, a cheery greeting.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: That’1l be Nancy and George and Annette. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 111 112 113 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 80.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Off you go. Enjoy yourself. EXT. EILIS’S HOUSE. EVENING 112 Waiting outside in the gleaming four-door saloon car are Nancy, GEORGE, her fiancee, and his friend JIM. Both men sporting the Rugby Club trademark blazers and Brylcreem. There is no sign of Annette. The men are in the front sea it’s George’s car - and Nancy is in the back. Eilis pause momentarily when she sees Jim. She smiles thinly and gets INT. GEORGE’S CAR. EVENING 113 Eilis settles herself in and George starts the car.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Eilis, this is Jim Farrell.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (cool) Hello. Jim turns around and shakes Eilis’s hand. He’s confident, direct, sincere, manly. If he didn’t come with rugby-club baggage, he might even be described as extremely attracti

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: It’s a great pleasure to meet you. Eilis nods. When Jim has turned around again, Eilis makes why-didn’t you-tell-me? face at Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (to George) We could try the Connaught Hotel bar. There may be a few of the fellas from the rugby club there. Eilis looks at Nancy, wanting her to say something; Nancy doesn’t even know there’s something to say.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (tartly) Do you have to be with other fellas from the rugby club all the time? Jim turns around again. He’s amused.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: No. But Nancy told us that we wouldn’t be allowed to talk to you, because you had too much to say to each other. So we're looking for company. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 81.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Oh. Well. She should probably apologise, but she doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Do you not like the fellas from the rugby club, Eilis? He tries to catch Jim’s eye, but Jim doesn’t want to get involved in this.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I don’t, particularly, George. Nancy nudges her and makes a pleading face. Eilis ignores her.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: When I first went to America, I missed every single thing about Enniscorthy except one.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: We’re not all the same.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: You all look the same. It’s the blazer and the hair-oil. Jim and George look at each other and laugh with recognit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get out of the car. Jim and George walk ahead - Eili hangs back deliberately so that she can talk to Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Why has he come? And where’s Annette?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: He saw you at Mass on Sunday morning, and he asked George if we could arrange a drink, just the four of us. And I knew you wouldn’t come if I told you. He’s very nice, so don’t be too hard on him.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Is this the same Jim Farrell that was engaged to Cathleen Cassidy? What happened to her? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 114 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: He broke it off. He didn’t think she was serious about him. He was very upset for a while, but he’s over her now.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Nancy, I’m.. She hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m going back.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: He knows that. But you can have a bit of fun while you’re here, can’t you? 82. 114 George and Jim wait for the girls to catch them up. Georg and Nancy then walk ahead. Jim slows his pace so that he talk to Eilis privately.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: How is your mother?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Oh, she’s...Well, she’s sad. (Beat) And she’s got much older, very quickly.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (sincerely) It was a terrible thing. We all went to the funeral Mass. My mother and father and myself.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I, I didn’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: My mother played golf with her, you know. She was very fond of her. It was... It was the saddest thing to happen in the town that I can remember. Jim is so pained and so genuine that Eilis can only look him with gratitude. She can’t speak, and she’s close to tears.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Thank you.  'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis, Nancy and George watch as Jim pays for the round o drinks at the bar: pints for the men, gin and bitter lemo for the girls.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: We can stand at the bar, George, can’t we? And the ladies can have their gossip over there. He gestures towards a quiet table in the corner of the ro After the conversation she had with Jim on the way in, Ei feels awkward.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Oh, we’re not going to talk about anything terribly exciting.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (disappointed) Oh, really? You’ve got nothing to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I'd love to hear something about New York. If I promise not to say anything, can I listen? Later. Jim, George and Nancy are listening to Eilis talki about her new life.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Ah, but that’s Manhattan. I live in Brooklyn, and I work in Brooklyn, and if I go out, I go out in Brooklyn, and the skyscrapers are across the river. I don’t even think about them, very often.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: But you’ve made friends?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Oh, the girls in the house aren't so bad, once you get used to them.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You don’t make it sound very glamorous.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: It’s not, really.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Not even..what do you call it? The department store where you work? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 84.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Bartocci’s? It sells lovely things. But I can’t afford many of them, and I don’t like the work.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: What would you like to do?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I want to do what Rose did. I want to work in an office, and deal with numbers. That’s why I’ve been studying so hard.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You should call in at Davis’s. They haven’t managed to replace Rose, you know. We do business with them, and they've been looking, but they can’t find anyone who’s reliable and qualified.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I‘1l be going back to New York straight after the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: But you might want to earn a little money in the meantime. I’m sure they’d be glad to have you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (teasing) Oh, you just want her to stay.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I’m only thinking of Eilis. He says this ambiguously, and with a smile. He doesn’t mi being teased, and he certainly doesn’t mind being teased this particular subject.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: D’you hear that, Eilis? He’s only thinking of you. Eilis blushes. She makes eye contact with Jim, and she lo away first. 116 EXT. EILIS’ HOUSE. NIGHT 116 Eilis emerges from George’s car, amid laughter. The eveni has clearly gone well. She walks towards her house and notices that the light in the front room is still on.  'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 85. 117 INT. DINING ROOM, EILIS’S HOUSE. NIGHT. 117 Eilis comes in to the front room. Mary is reading the newspaper in an armchair.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How was your evening?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: It was very nice, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Was that Jim Farrell I saw in the car with them?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: It was. Mary raises her eyebrows quizzically. Eilis isn’t biting.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: His parents are moving, you know. They're retiring to the country. He’1l be in that big house on his own.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He’s a catch for someone. (Beat) Did you see the air-mail letter that came for you?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No. Thank you. She's embarrassed by something. Mary studies her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: One of your new friends in America, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I expect so. Goodnight, Mummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis rushes into the bedroom, sits on the bed, tears ope her letter and reads it voraciously. We have seen somethi like this before - when she was in Brooklyn, devouring letters from Ireland.  120 121 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis walking through the streets of Enniscorthy, carryin grocery shopping. She smiles and says hello to a couple o people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis comes in through the front door with the shopping. bustles out of the front room into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, thank goodness you’re back.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (alarmed) What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: A lad from Davis’s came round. They have a problem in their accounts department and they need you up there straight away.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (relieved) Is that all? I’1l just put the shopping away.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, no, leave it. Straight away, the young fella said.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter what he said, Mother. I’m not an employee. I'd be doing them a favour.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Please, let me do the shopping. She blocks Eilis’s way, takes the bags off her impatientl Eilis sighs, turns around, goes out of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIA, a woman in her mid-thirties, ushers Eilis through large outer office where several people are working into smaller office. On the desk there is a framed photograph Eilis. She sees it immediately, but doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: The problem is that it’s our busy season, so all the drivers and mill- workers did overtime last week. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 87.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, they’ve all filled out their overtime slips, which are here... She picks a pile of slips up off the desk.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: But there’s been nobody to work it all out and add it to their wage slips, and some of the men have started to complain. And I can’t blame them. As you can see, it’s all a terrible mess.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: If you leave me for a couple of hours, I can work out a system so that whoever comes in after me won't have any trouble. I’1l come and find you if I have any questions.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You're sure you don’t need me in here?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m sure. Later. Eilis is completely absorbed in her work - this, a all, is what she has always wanted to do. At the end of the day, the office is in impeccable shape Eilis has tidied up all the overtime slips, and has wage packets lined up in alphabetical order in a box. Just as is standing up to go, there is a perfunctory knock on the door and MR BROWN, owner of Davis’s, walks in.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Hello, Eilis. Maria has been telling me that you’ve done the most marvellous job here. We should have known you would, of course. You're Rose’s sister, after all.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: I’m told you have a certificate in book-keeping. Is it American book- keeping?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I got the certificate in America, but the two systems are very similar. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 88.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Well, we'll certainly need someone to deal with wages and so on during the busy season, so I'd like you to continue on a part-time basis. Let’s see how that goes, and then we'll speak again.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I will be going back to the United States soon.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: As I say. Let’s you and I speak again before we make any firm decisions one way or the other. Eilis hesitates for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Brown. Of course. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Now, if you go and see Maria, she’ll have your money for today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gorgeous, sunny, windy August day. Nancy, George, Eilis Jim stand on the cliffs looking out to sea. They are carr towels and bathing suits. Down beneath them is a glorious empty sandy beach.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (wonderingly) I’d forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: This.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Do you have beaches in Brooklyn? Eilis smiles, remembering her day with Tony at Coney Isla

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes. But..they’re different. The one I’ve been to is, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Stones? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122 123 124 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 89.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (confused) Stones?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Are the beaches stony?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Oh. It’s not that. They’re very crowded.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: There will probably be quite a few walkers here later.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (smiles) Yes, I’m sure. It’s still not the same.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I’m sure it’s not. (Sadly) We don’t really know anything of the rest of the world. We must seem very backward to you now.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Of course not. You seem calm, and civilized. And charming. To her own amazement, Eilis is flirting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four make their way down the path to the beach. Georg holds Nancy’s hand as she jumps down the last big step; J offers his hand to Eilis. She hesitates, and then takes i There is a moment between them as she reaches the sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Eilis walk behind Nancy and George along the beac

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: My mother wanted you to know that the golf club is inaugurating a prize in Rose’s name. A special trophy, for the best score by a lady newcomer at the club. She was always very nice to the newcomers, my mother says. Eilis stops, a little overcome. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 90.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I hope you're pleased.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course. (Beat) So every year, somebody will win the Rose Lacey Trophy?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Every year. As long as there’s a golf club. Eilis starts to walk again, lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I think my mother would like you to come along and present it to the first winner. Oh, and she’d like to meet you, by the way. I’m supposed to arrange a time when you can come for tea.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Thank you. I’d like that. (Beat) I wish it had been like this before I went. Before Rose died.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: There was no place for me here before. And now...I have a job, and She makes a vague gesture, which seems to include Jim, an trails off.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (off in the distance) Here? She dumps the towels where she is standing. Later. Nancy, George and Jim are engaged in the age-old a inelegant struggle between towels and immodesty, as they to put their bathing costumes on. They hop on one leg, cu and giggle. Eilis takes off her blouse and skirt to revea the bathing costume (and more of the tan) that she got in America. Nancy and George are impressed with the simplici of the idea; Jim is just impressed generally.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Is that an American trick?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s a good one, isn’t it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 124 125 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s depressing, though, that we don’t think of things like that, isn’t it? I mean, how long have they known about it? A hundred years, probably.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (reverently) I don’t think they had bathing suits like that a hundred years ago. And we still don’t have them now. Nancy and George exchange knowing, smiling glances.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Come on. The four of them skip down the sand into the sea. INT. TONY’S HOUSE. NIGHT 91. 124 125 Frankie, Tony’s little brother, is lying on his bed in hi pyjamas, reading. Tony comes in.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You want to go see the Dodgers on Saturday? Frankie sits bolt upright.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: OK, will you do something for me?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: What? Tony closes the bedroom door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So if you laugh, or say anything about this to anyone else in the family, you don’t get to see the Dodgers on Saturday. Or any other day of the season. Also, you get a beating.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s just better if I don’t get involved. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 92.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I really need your help.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: So stop telling me you’re going to beat me up. I like the Dodgers, but I could listen on the radio. Tony produces a letter from his pocket. It’s crumpled, an little grubby.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You know you’re the best writer and reader in the family?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: (cocky) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m trying to write to Eilis, and I want it to be, I dunno...

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You wrote before already. About five times.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but... They’re no good, Frankie. And she’s only written back once. She’s never read my writing before. I’m worried I’m putting her off me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I'm eight years old. I don’t know anything about kissing.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You don’t need to know anything about kissing. You need to know about spelling and, and sentences.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Grammar.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Will you look? He hands Frankie the letter hopefully, and a little desperately.  126 127 128 129 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis, Jim, Nancy and George in the sea. Nancy and George physically intimate with each other, in the way that Tony Eilis were at Coney Island; Eilis and Jim are further apa of course, but by no means distant, and playful with each other. Music - the score at this point is wistful, regret heartbreaking.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (in a halting, unconfident monotone ) Dear Eilis, I hope that you are doing well in Ireland. I hope that your mother is feeling less sad. It will not be long before your friend gets married and you can come home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis back at Davis's, in her one-woman accounts departme She's animated, confident, her intelligence alive in her face. She’s tallying up a row of figures in a ledger. On desk, there is a framed photograph of Rose. A driver knoc on the door, she smiles, hands him a wage packet.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This week it is like the whole world’s basements are flooding. I have fixed three. I have been working hard. I have been saving money.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Everybody asks me about you all the time.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You missed out an ‘e’ I think. It’s “everybody”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A different beach. Jim and Eilis, walking along the water edge, carrying their shoes.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Anyway, I think that is all my news. Mom and Dad and my brothers all say hello.  130 131 132

dialogues.speaker: 132A
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 94. INT. KITCHEN, EILIS’S HOUSE. NIGHT 130 Mary gets up from her armchair, pulls back the curtains. sees Jim's car parked outside on the street.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I think about you most minutes of most days. Even when I go to see the Dodgers I do not concentrate on the games. (To Frankie) I guess I got “concentrate” wrong, right? Mary peers intently into the darkness. She, like us, can Eilis and Jim kissing chastely.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: With love, your Tony. (Beat) So how should I change it? Mary smiles. INT. EILIS’S HOUSE. DAY 131 Eilis comes in from work. On the hall table there is an airmail letter. She picks it up. She is about to open it there and then, but she decides not to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis sits down on the bed with the letter. She stares at crude but neat handwriting. She goes to open it again - a again, she can’t bring herself to do it. Close on the top drawer of the chest of drawers by Eilis’ bed. Her hand opens the drawer, puts the letter on top of several other identical letters, all apparently unopened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Eilis are eating at the Connaught. Jim is wearing blazer, and he’s nervous. Eilis recognises his nerves and vulnerablity, and she’s grateful for them.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No hair oil. And that’s not a blazer, it’s a sports jacket. Have you come out in disguise, Jim Farrell? Are you trying to trick me? Jim laughs self-deprecatingly, blushes, and smooths his h embarrassed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 94a.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I knew what you meant, when you said we're all the same. And it made me think that my life must seem very easy to you. I’m going to run my father’s bar, and I’m going to live in my parents’ house. I can see what that must look like from the outside. But it doesn’t feel like that.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: What does it feel like? Jim thinks. Later. Eilis is eating a roast dinner. Jim doesn’t seem t have touched the food on his plate. He is in full flow.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: And I’ve never been anywhere. I have never even been to England. I'd like to see London, and Paris, and Rome. And New York. It frightens me, the thought of dying without ever leaving Ireland. And there are other things, too... Later. They are drinking coffee.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I wanted to ask you a thousand things and all I’ve done is talked.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m glad.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s the day of Nancy and George’s wedding. Jim, Eilis an Mary, all dressed in Sunday best, are walking towards the church, Mary on Eilis’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to be sitting right at the back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 94B.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Oh, we’ll make sure you get the best seats in the house. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 133 134 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 95.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (alarmed) Oh, it wouldn’t feel right, sitting up there with Nancy and George.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (smiling) We'll find the second-best seats in the house, then. Would you like me to run ahead and save a couple of places, Mrs Lacey?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Would you mind, Jim? That would be grand. Jim walks briskly ahead.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He’s a real gentleman, isn’t he?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (neutral) He is.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He came along at just the right time for us. Eilis says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Is he why you changed your ticket again?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Oh, no. They need me at Davis's too much for me to think about going for a week or two, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy and George getting married. Nancy is looking into George’s eyes and reciting her vows.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I promise to be true to you in good times and in bad, in sickness and in health. I will love you and honour you all the days of my life. We see Jim, Eilis and Mary in the congregation. Jim tries steal a sideways glance at Eilis, but she won’t catch his eye, and, to Jim at least, her expression is unreadable - certainly she’s not smiling. If anything, she looks afrai  135 136 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Nancy and George get into the car that will take them the church and the reception, Eilis has been caught by on Mary’s friends, Mrs Byrne.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BYRNE
dialogues.text: (knowingly) Your mother tells me you things are working out for you very well in Enniscorthy, Eilis. Eilis doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: It was a lovely service.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BYRNE
dialogues.text: And Mr and Mrs Farrell are moving out to Glenbrien, so Jim will...

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (abrupt) Yes, I know. (Beat) Jim and I promised my mother we'd take her back to the car. She says she can’t remember where we parked it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BYRNE
dialogues.text: Oh, do you hear that? “Jim and I! Jim and I!”. It won’t be long now, by the sound of it, and your mother will have a wonderful day out. Eilis smiles thinly.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Will you excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Eilis are slow-dancing to the band, along with several other couples, in the ballroom of the hotel. It’s clearly the fag-end of the evening, and many of the older people have gone home, apart from those too incapable of stirring themselves.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Can we talk? Eilis pulls her face away, looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: What about? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 97.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: About...Well, the future. Eilis takes a breath. She can guess what’s coming.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I can’t just let you go back to America without saying anything. I'd regret it for the rest of my life. So: I don’t want you to go. I want you to stay here, with me. Eilis stiffens perceptibly.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: And that means asking you another question, I know that, but I don’t want to bombard you. I’1l save that one for later. He looks at her expectantly. She shrugs helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Thank you. (Beat) I’m...I’m grateful. And I’m flattered.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: But that’s all?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No. No, of course not. It’s just...I had imagined a different life for myself.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I understand. But your life here could be just as good. Better, even, maybe. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 136 137 138 139 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 98.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Eilis returns to her previous position: she holds Jim clo to her, and puts her head on his shoulder. That way she c demonstrate how she feels without having to say any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis is sitting on her bed surrounded by Tony’s letters. has an air-mail pad on her knee and a pen is poised above paper. She starts to write.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Dear Tony, She stops again. There’s a pause.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Thank you for your letters. Another pause. I want you to know that... She stops again.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (out loud, agonised) I don’t know what I want you to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim lives on the edge of Enniscorthy, in a pretty detache house set back from the road. It’s not big, but it’s bigg than her mother’s house. His car turns into the gravel dr He jumps out, runs round, opens the door for Eilis, who i wearing Sunday best, a nicely-cut dress that she couldn’t have bought in Ireland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Farrell, a large, homely, pleasant woman is pouring t for Eilis in the small back garden of the house. Jim and Eilis are sitting on chairs at the garden table; Jim’s fa is sitting away from them, smoking a pipe on a bench at t end of the garden. It’s a hot day, but there is plenty of shade.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FARRELL
dialogues.text: (to her husband) Will you finish that wretched pipe and sit with us?

dialogues.speaker: MR FARRELL
dialogues.text: I can hear perfectly well from where I am. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 99.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FARRELL
dialogues.text: We're not here to provide you with entertainment.

dialogues.speaker: MR FARRELL
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t you worry. I found that out many years ago. Jim rolls his eyes at Eilis. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FARRELL
dialogues.text: (provocatively quiet) Just ignore him, Eilis. It’s as well Jim takes after me, not him.

dialogues.speaker: MR FARRELL
dialogues.text: (shouting) Speak up!

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (a little louder than necessary) Are you looking forward to your move?

dialogues.speaker: MRS FARRELL
dialogues.text: (still quiet) Ah, we'll miss Enniscorthy. But it’s lovely and quiet in Glenbrien. Over on the bench, Mr Farrell puts down his pipe in irritation and stomps over to join them.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Mother’s worried about leaving me here on my own. She thinks I'11 destroy the place.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FARRELL
dialogues.text: (carefully) I’m hoping you won’t be on your own forever.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m sure he won't. Almost before the words are out of her mouth, Eilis can s that she’s said more than she meant to, and we can see sh feels panicky. She tries to clarify her position.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
