dialogues.text: I mean.. But she can’t find words with the necessary ambiguity - unsurprisingly, given that she doesn’t know what she feel Mrs Farrell looks at Jim meaningfully. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 139 140 141 142 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 100.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: It’s clear that Eilis has her approval. Jim smiles. He lo happy and proud - and, to us, vulnerable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis standing at Rose’s grave. She has just left fresh flowers by the headstone.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: You're the only person I can talk to, Rose. There’s nobody else. Not Tony, my husband. My husband! Not Jim. Not mother. Oh, Rose. Can you imagine If I told mummy that I was going to marry Jim? That would be everything she wanted. She wouldn't be alone. And I could be happy, I know I could. I'd be happy with Jim here, at home. And I could be happy with Tony in America. I know that, too... I wish I could do nothing. I wish I could float above it all, watching. Like you. EXT. EILIS’S HOUSE, STREET. DAY 141 Eilis has just returned from visiting Rose’s grave. She i about to walk down the path into her house when she sees Mary, Miss Kelly’s shop assistant, walking towards her briskly.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Mary!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I was just coming to fetch you.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (amused) To fetch me? I haven’t worked for Miss Kelly for a long time, Mary. I may call in to see her soon, if that’s what she wants.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (anxious) Please come, Eilis. She told me not to come back without you. You know what she’s like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kelly is waiting at the door of the shop where Eilis used to work as Eilis and Mary approach. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 142 143 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 101.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: You look after things for five minutes while I’m upstairs with Eilis, please, Mary. There are no customers in there at the moment, so I don’t think you can make too much of a mess of things. She leads Eilis round the side of the shop, where there i entrance to Miss Kelly’s home above the shop. She opens t door without saying anything, and Eilis follows her insid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dingy room, full of old furniture and dust and no colou We see the dust motes in the afternoon sunlight. Eilis an Miss Kelly enter the room, and Miss Kelly sits down in an armchair. She gestures at Eilis to sit on a smaller armch facing her. Eilis perches on it, unwilling to relax.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: So. How have you been getting on?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Very well, thanks, Miss Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: I heard that you’re working over at Davis's? In the accounts department?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: And there’s lots of talk about you and young Jim Farrell.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Ah, well. You know what people are like. They love to talk. Miss Kelly smiles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: Yes. Do you remember Mrs Brady? Eilis thinks, or pretends to.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: She usually comes into the shop on Sunday morning for her rashers. This hasn't helped. Eilis still looks blank. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 102.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: No? Well, you have a very busy life now. What with one thing and another. Miss Kelly pauses for a moment. She’s enjoying unsettling Eilis.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: Anyway, Mrs Brady has a niece living in Brooklyn. Eilis is now beginning to feel uneasy - we can almost see chill that is beginning to run through her.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: The world is a small place, isn’t it? She had a letter from her a couple of weeks back.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: And what did it say?

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: Oh, only that she’d been to a wedding at the registry office, and her husband had bumped into a girl from Enniscorthy who was getting married there.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I’m not sure what you’re telling me, Miss Kelly. He didn’t bump into me. This has only the virtue of being literally true. Eilis i visibly shaking. Miss Kelly is loving this. There is unambiguous pleasure on her face.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: Oh, you can’t fool me, Miss Lacey. Although I’m not sure that’s your name any longer, is it? He couldn’t remember. Something Italian, he thought. Suddenly, Eilis finds the will to resist her.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (quietly) I’d forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KELLY
dialogues.text: (snorting disbelief) You'd forgotten! What a thing for- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 143 144 145 146 147 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 103.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I'd forgotten what this town is like. What were you planning to do, Miss Kelly? Keep me away from Jim? Stop me from going back to America? Perhaps you didn’t even know. Perhaps it was enough for you to know that you could ruin me. She stands up.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: My name is Eilis Fiorello. She meets Miss Kelly’s stare and then leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis comes out of Miss Kelly’s flat and closes the door. stops for a moment, closes her eyes, then walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Eilis walking in to the local post office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minutes later. Eilis is leaning against the wall in a telephone kiosk, shaken by her encounter. The telephone rings. She answers it immediately.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Thank you.... Hello? I would like to make a reservation for the next available sailing from Cobh to New York.... INT. DINING ROOM, EILIS’S HOUSE. EVENING 147 Eilis and Mary, eating their dinner. Eilis is drawn, distracted; Mary is content and chatty. We join her in mi flow.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I think people even spend more money after a wedding. Nancy's mother must have been in every shop in the town. She was buying firelighters in Broom’s. Firelighters! In August! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 103A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Close on Eilis. She can hardly bear to listen to this. Sh begins to weep silently. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 104.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But she’d seen Mrs Stapleton in there, and she hadn’t had a chance to go through the whole day in detail with her, so... Finally Mary notices her tears.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Eilis, what’s the matter? Has something happened with Jim?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Mummy, I’m sorry. I’m so sorry. I’m married. I got married in Brooklyn before I came home. I should have told you. I should have told you the minute I got back. Mary puts down her knife and fork. She holds on to the ta as if to steady herself.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And you kept it from me all this time? Eilis closes her eyes. She cannot bear the pain she is causing her mother.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So you're going back? Eilis nods.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes. Tomorrow. A very brief expression of shock appears on her mother’s face.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I want to be with him. I want to be with my husband.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Of course. Is he nice?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (softly, heartbroken) He would have to be nice, if you married him. The letters that came... I didn’t want to ask. Eilis is crying again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 147 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I know you didn’t. And I didn’t want to tell you. Mary stands up.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Are you on the early train? Eilis nods.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I’m going to bed.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Oh, mummy...It’s not even eight o'clock. You don’t have to..

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I’m very tired. And I'd rather say goodbye now, and only once. Eilis stands up and they embrace.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: If you weren’t married, would you still be going back?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: (helplessly) Yes. And then, recognising that this admission causes fresh pain...

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Perhaps you’1l write to me about him when you get back?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Have a safe journey. Goodnight, Eilis. 105. 147 She walks out of the room, dignified, determined, broken. Eilis sits back down at the dinner table and puts her hea her hands. Montage:  'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 106. 147A INT. EILIS’S HOUSE - ROSE’S BEDROOM. DAY 147A Eilis is standing in the doorway looking at the empty roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis standing outside a large house a little way out of town. She hesitates, walks down the path and puts a lette through the letter-box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis sitting in a train carriage, looking out of the win

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, dressed for work, stoops to pick up an envelope on t mat in the hallway. He opens it, starts to read the lette contains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis, standing with a few other passengers on the deck o passenger ship looking back at the dock as it disappears. young-looking teenage girl standing a few feet away is watching too. She turns to Eilis.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL ON DECK
dialogues.text: So are you away to live in America? Eilis doesn’t turn towards the voice.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL ON DECK
dialogues.text: Just visiting?

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No. I live there already.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL ON DECK
dialogues.text: Really? What’s it like? Eilis smiles wearily.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: It’s a big place.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL ON DECK
dialogues.text: I’m going to live in Brooklyn, New York. Do you know it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 106A.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 151 152 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 107.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL ON DECK
dialogues.text: People say that there’s so many Irish people there, it’s like home. Is that right? Finally, Eilis turns to study the girl - takes in her you and her innocence, and her fear.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s just like home. The girl smiles gratefully. Eilis turns away. Suddenly sh thinks better of her unfriendliness, and turns back to th girl.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: You're not to eat.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL ON DECK
dialogues.text: Oh. Right. (Beat) But I might be there years. Eilis smiles.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: No, you can eat when you get there. But don’t eat on the boat. It’1l stop you getting so sick. Do you promise me?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL ON DECK
dialogues.text: I promise.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS
dialogues.text: And in a moment, I want you to go straight down to your cabin and lock the bathroom door on your side. When next door starts hammering, you can negotiate.... When you get to Immigration, keep your eyes wide open, and look as if you know where you’re going. You have to think like an American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the girl joining the back of a dispiritingly long queue - the same desperation and poverty ahead of her tha Eilis had to deal with when she arrived in New York. Eili walks past her quickly down a different path - she gives girl on the deck a nod and a smile of encouragement. She joins a tiny queue over which hangs a sign saying US CITIZENS ONLY. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 152 153 'Brooklyn' YELLOW Script Dated 24th April 2014 108.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You'll feel so homesick that you’1ll want to die, and there’s nothing you can do about it apart from endure it. But you will, and it won’t kill you. And one day the sun will come out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eilis is leaning against a wall opposite a three-story brownstone in Brooklyn. She has her eyes closed as she so up the last of a late-summer sunny day. The front door of brownstone opens, and two men, dressed in overalls and carrying tools, come out chatting. One of them is Tony. E sees him before he sees her, and the camera stays on him a moment - we notice his openness, his good humour, his innocence.

dialogues.speaker: EILIS, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And you'll realise that this is where your life is. Tony sees her. He stops in his tracks, smiles broadly, ru across the road. For a moment he’s worried about the reception he’s getting. Eilis’s expression is difficult t read, and for a moment he looks at her anxiously, but she opens her arms to him. Freeze on their embrace.
